questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of increasing shortness of breath. He has been using two pillows at night but frequently wakes up feeling as if he is choking. Five months ago, he underwent surgery for the creation of an arteriovenous fistula in his left upper arm. He has hypertension and chronic kidney disease due to reflux nephropathy. He receives hemodialysis three times a week. His current medications are enalapril, vitamin D3, erythropoietin, sevelamer, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 103/min and bounding, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 106/58 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral pitting pedal edema. There is jugular venous distention. A prominent bruit is heard over the brachiocephalic arteriovenous fistula. There are crackles heard at both lung bases. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arteriovenous (AV) fistula aneurysms may manifest with focal enlargement of the graft and pose a risk of infection or rupture. However, this patient does not present with any abnormal graft enlargement on examination or overlying skin changes (e.g., ulceration or infection). Moreover, an arteriovenous fistula aneurysm would not explain his current symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome would not manifest with symptoms of heart failure, but rather headache and disorientation secondary to cerebral edema. The edema is caused by osmotic shifts in patients initiating dialysis for the first time and is potentially due to the rapid reduction of blood urea nitrogen. This syndrome is much less prevalent today due to preventative measures such as earlier initiation of dialysis (before urea nitrogen levels become significantly elevated) or starting dialysis more slowly to correct the uremia at a slower rate.

C) INCORRECT:

As the patient is afebrile, normotensive, and has no identifiable source of infection, sepsis is an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Although pulmonary embolism (PE) may cause acute shortness of breath and tachycardia, the duration of the patient's symptoms and the lack of unilateral leg edema, risk factors for deep venous thrombosis and PE (e.g., major surgery in last 4 weeks, active cancer), or calf tenderness make PE an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis can manifest with signs of heart failure, as seen in this patient. Additionally, uremia is a potential cause of the condition and this patient has chronic kidney disease. However, the lack of chest pain makes pericarditis unlikely, and the patient should not be uremic since he is currently undergoing dialysis three times a week. Additionally, he has no pericardial knock, and the presence of an S3 gallop suggests a different diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Arteriovenous (AV) fistulas cause a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance because they allow shunting of blood from high-pressure arterial circulation to the low-pressure venous system. This shunting causes a decrease in systemic vascular resistance, which results in elevated heart rate and decreased effective circulating volume, thereby triggering activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). RAAS activation, in turn, causes retention of sodium and water, resulting in increased cardiac filling pressures with elevated cardiac output, which may culminate in a state of high-output heart failure (high-output HF). This patient requires immediate surgical division of the fistula to reverse current symptoms and prevent irreversible myocardial damage.

Other common causes of high-output HF include pregnancy, anemia, hyperthyroidism, and wet beriberi.
questions.hint: The patient might also experience pulsatile tinnitus as a result of his current condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-month history of worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. While he used to be able to walk 4–5 blocks at a time, he now has to pause every 2 blocks. He also reports waking up from having to urinate at least once every night for the past 5 months. Recently, he has started using two pillows to avoid waking up coughing with acute shortness of breath at night. He has a history of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medications include daily amlodipine and prazosin, but he reports having trouble adhering to his medication regimen. His pulse is 72/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities. Auscultation shows an S4 gallop and fine bibasilar rales. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following pathophysiologic changes in this patient?

choices.text: Increased tone of efferent renal arterioles

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The reduced CO seen in CHF results in organ hypoperfusion, which also affects the kidneys. Reduced renal blood flow leads to compensatory activation of the RAAS system. Angiotensin II causes vasoconstriction of the afferent and efferent arterioles within the kidney, decreasing the net renal blood flow. Vasoconstriction is, however, more pronounced in the efferent arteriole, which results in an increase in intraglomerular pressure to maintain the glomerular filtration rate. In combination with the other effects of RAAS activation (aldosterone-induced renal Na+/H2O resorption and systemic vasoconstriction), this maintains CO.

Although RAAS activation is a compensatory mechanism to maintain the CO in patients with CHF, prolonged renal hypoperfusion (particularly in conjunction with precipitating factors, such as NSAID use and dehydration) can lead to renal insufficiency.
Image Description:

Reduced cardiac output results in the activation of compensatory mechanisms (i.e., ADH and BNP production, activation of the renin-angiotensin system and sympathetic nervous system) in an attempt to restore cardiac output.

Cardiac remodeling and increases in afterload both have a negative effect on cardiac output. Increases in heart rate and preload have a positive effect on cardiac output. The net effect of these compensatory mechanisms may be sufficient to restore cardiac output. If not, the cycle repeats.

B) INCORRECT:

Surfactant ensures low alveolar surface tension to prevent alveolar collapse. This patient has signs of pulmonary edema, which is characterized by fluid accumulation within the pulmonary interstitium and alveoli. This, in turn, causes increased alveolar surface tension, which results in alveolar collapse. Patients with alveolar collapse present with dyspnea, decreased exercise capacity, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

An increase in bicarbonate excretion can be a compensatory mechanism in patients with respiratory alkalosis or a cause of metabolic acidosis (e.g., in type 2 acute tubular acidosis). This patient presents with CHF, which would not result in increased bicarbonate excretion. Instead, elevated aldosterone levels due to upregulation of RAAS lead to an increase in renal sodium resorption in exchange for both hydrogen and potassium. This would cause a net loss of hydrogen in urine. For this reason, patients with CHF are prone to developing metabolic alkalosis.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with CHF, which is characterized by reduced CO and activation of the sympathetic and RAAS system. This compensatory mechanism results in systemic vasoconstriction, which increases rather than decreases systemic vascular resistance.

E) INCORRECT:

An increase in left ventricular compliance is seen in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy (eccentric hypertrophy), which results in systolic dysfunction. This patient, however, presents with CHF that is most likely due to chronic hypertension, as suggested by his history of poor compliance with his medication regimen. Chronic hypertension results predominantly in concentric ventricular hypertrophy, which leads to decreased left ventricular compliance (as indicated by the S4 gallop seen here) and diastolic dysfunction.

F) INCORRECT:

An increase in potassium retention occurs secondary to hypoaldosteronism. However, this patient presents with CHF, characterized by reduced CO and organ hypoperfusion, which also affects the kidneys. Reduced renal blood flow results in RAAS activation. This patient is therefore more likely to have elevated aldosterone levels, resulting in increased renal Na+ and H2O resorption as well as potassium excretion.
questions.hint: This patient has classic signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure (CHF), including dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, nocturia, bibasilar rales from pulmonary edema (suggestive of left-sided heart failure), and pitting edema (suggestive of right-sided heart failure). CHF is characterized by reduced cardiac output (CO), which activates numerous compensatory neurohumoral mechanisms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of worsening shortness of breath. The symptoms occur when he climbs the stairs to his apartment on the third floor and when he goes to bed. He gained 2.3 kg (5 lbs) in the past 5 days. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, alcoholic steatosis, and osteoarthritis. He underwent surgical repair of a ventricular septal defect at the age of 4 months. He started taking ibuprofen and simvastatin one week ago. He drinks two to three beers daily after work. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), his pulse is 114/min, and his blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention and 2+ pitting edema in his lower extremities. Crackles are heard over the lower lung fields bilaterally. On cardiac examination, a late-diastolic heart sound is heard. Echocardiography shows concentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcoholic cardiomyopathy is one of the most common causes of dilated cardiomyopathy and a common complication from long-term alcohol use. In patients with this condition, an early-diastolic heart sound (S3) can be heard due to a sudden rush of blood into the volume-overloaded ventricles. While concurrent alcoholic cardiomyopathy cannot be completely excluded in this patient, the echocardiographic finding of concentric hypertrophy and S4 heart sound make another underlying cause more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Severe pericardial effusion (cardiac tamponade) can present with Beck triad of jugular venous distention, hypotension, and muffled (distant) heart sounds. Other clinical findings include pulsus paradoxus and loss of maximal apical impulse, which are not seen in this patient. While pericardial effusion could have played a role in the development of this patient's pulmonary edema, it typically affects the right ventricle whereas this patient shows signs of left ventricular dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Simvastatin does not exacerbate CHF. This patient also does not show signs of hepatotoxicity or myalgia, both common adverse effects of simvastatin.

D) CORRECT:

Arterial hypertension (HTN) is one of the most common causes of CHF. Chronic HTN causes long-term concentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle and, if left untreated, can ultimately result in left-sided heart failure, which manifests with symptoms of pulmonary congestion (e.g., exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, bibasilar crackles), tachycardia, and S4 heart sound. Long-term left-sided heart failure may eventually progress to right-sided heart failure as a result of chronic volume overload and manifest with symptoms of fluid retention (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distention). Although this patient's blood pressure is only mildly elevated, it is most likely attributed to the backflow of blood into the right chambers of the heart and a consequent decrease in left ventricular output.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient underwent a correction of his ventricular septal defect (VSD) as a young child. Rates of treatment failure are low if the condition is corrected early enough. In chronic VSD, right-sided volume overload caused by an untreated left-to-right shunt eventually leads to shunt reversal and pulmonary hypertension, also known as Eisenmenger syndrome. Symptoms include central cyanosis, digital clubbing, and right-sided heart failure. Patients usually do not present with bibasilar crackles in the lungs (which is a finding in left-sided heart failure).
questions.hint: This older patient shows signs of both left ventricular dysfunction and right ventricular dysfunction. This presentation is consistent with an exacerbation of advanced congestive heart failure (CHF), most likely triggered by a recent NSAID use.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath. The symptoms most commonly occur when lying flat at night. He also reports shortness of breath when walking up the two flights of stairs to his apartment. He reports no chest pain. Medical history is remarkable for myocardial infarction 2 years ago. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He does not exercise. His medications include aspirin, lisinopril, bisoprolol, and atorvastatin. Pulse is 85/min and blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows an extra heart sound during early diastole on auscultation. Faint crackles are heard at both lung bases. There is 1+ ankle edema bilaterally. Cardiac ultrasonography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 0.35. Which of the following hemodynamic changes are most likely present in this patient?



Cardiac output (CO)
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)
Left ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV)
Total peripheral resistance (TPR)



A
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


B
Decreased
unchanged
decreased
increased


C
Decreased
decreased
decreased
increased


D
Decreased
increased
increased
increased


E
Increased
decreased
decreased
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These parameters suggest late-stage untreated septic shock. Elevated inflammatory mediators lead to systemic vasodilation and decreased TPR. This results in decreased effective circulating volume, which causes decreased venous return. Decreased venous return leads to decreased LVEDV and decreased PCWP. Eventually, the heart can no longer compensate and CO begins to fall.

B) INCORRECT:

These parameters can be found in obstructive causes of shock such as massive pulmonary embolism or pericardial tamponade. Venous return remains the same but cannot be transmitted through the heart chambers effectively. This results in increased central venous pressure but decreased LVEDV and CO. PCWP may be decreased or unchanged depending on the extent of obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

These parameters suggest hypovolemic shock. Decreased circulating blood volume leads to decreased venous return, resulting in reduced blood flow to the left ventricle, which causes decreased LVEDV and low PCWP. Decreased CO and effective circulating volume activate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and sympathetic nervous system, resulting in increased TPR.

D) CORRECT:

In systolic dysfunction, poor contractility leads to decreased stroke volume and cardiac output. In response to decreased cardiac output, there is compensatory activation of the RAAS and sympathetic nervous system, resulting in increased TPR. In addition, incomplete ventricular emptying during systole results in left ventricular volume overload, which results in increased LVEDV. Increased LVEDV and poor forward flow cause increased left ventricular pressure, which is transmitted to the left atrium, resulting in increased PCWP.

E) INCORRECT:

These parameters can be found in the early stages of septic shock. Inflammatory mediators lead to systemic vasodilation and decreased TPR. This results in decreased effective circulating volume, which causes decreased venous return. With decreased venous return, there is decreased LVEDV and decreased PCWP. In the early stages of sepsis, the heart can become hyperdynamic, resulting in increased CO.
questions.hint: Features of pulmonary congestion (exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, bibasilar crackles) and an S3 gallop along with a history of myocardial infarction suggest congestive heart failure (CHF) most likely due to ischemic heart disease. A decreased left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) indicates systolic dysfunction.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and swollen legs for the past 4 weeks. She has tried sleeping in a raised position using 2 pillows but still wakes up occasionally from a choking sensation. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, arterial hypertension, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her sister has polymyalgia rheumatica. Her current medications include insulin, enalapril, and omeprazole. She has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. Examination shows an enlarged tongue, pitting edema below the knees, and jugular venous distention. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6100/mm3, erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 62 mm/h, and serum creatinine is 2.1 mg/dL. An ECG shows sinus rhythm and low-voltage QRS complexes. Echocardiography shows symmetrical left ventricular hypertrophy, reduced diastolic filling, and an ejection fraction of 55%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endocardial fibroelastosis can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy, but it most commonly affects infants in the first year of life and would not explain the recent development of symptoms in this patient or the finding of macroglossia.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic sclerosis can result in restrictive cardiomyopathy. However, this condition typically causes patchy myocardial fibrosis leading to systolic ventricular dysfunction or, more often, diastolic ventricular dysfunction. Systemic sclerosis can also present with esophageal hypomotility; although this patient reports a choking sensation, her presentation is more consistent with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea due to heart failure or obstructive sleep apnea due to macroglossia given that she wakes up at night and her symptoms are not postprandial. Characteristic facial features in patients with systemic sclerosis include mask-like facies, a shortened frenulum, and microstomia accompanied by characteristic perioral wrinkles rather than macroglossia.

C) CORRECT:

Plasma cell dyscrasias such as multiple myeloma (MM) can be complicated by AL amyloidosis, which causes widespread protein deposition in several organs, including the heart and tongue, with consequent development of restrictive cardiomyopathy and macroglossia. Restrictive cardiomyopathy typically manifests as heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, while macroglossia may cause obstructive sleep apnea, which can result in a choking sensation at night. Highly elevated ESR, Hb < 10 g/dL, and serum creatinine > 2 mg/dL are consistent with MM. Serum protein electrophoresis is the best initial test to detect monoclonal gammopathy in both conditions, but bone marrow biopsy and a tissue amyloid stain are required to confirm the diagnosis of MM and AL amyloidosis, respectively.

See “Overview of systemic amyloidosis” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiac involvement of hemochromatosis typically manifests with dilated cardiomyopathy, although it can also cause restrictive cardiomyopathy. About 50% of patients with hemochromatosis develop diabetes mellitus from the accumulation of iron in the pancreas. However, this patient lacks other typical clinical manifestations of hemochromatosis, including skin pigmentation and liver disease. Moreover, this diagnosis does not explain the finding of macroglossia.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are uncommon extraarticular manifestations and do not include restrictive cardiomyopathy but rather pericarditis and myocarditis. This patient does not have signs of myocarditis or pericarditis, such as fever or chest pain, and these conditions would not explain the tongue findings. Like other chronic inflammatory conditions, RA can also cause reactive amyloidosis (AA amyloidosis) in rare cases, which typically manifests with renal and gastrointestinal involvement. Unlike another form of amyloidosis, macroglossia and restrictive cardiomyopathy would not be expected in reactive amyloidosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Viral myocarditis can cause acute heart failure and an elevated ESR. Although myocarditis may result in dilated cardiomyopathy with a reduced ejection fraction, restrictive cardiomyopathy with preserved ejection fraction is not typical. If the pericardium is involved (perimyocarditis), pericardial effusions can lead to low-voltage on ECG; however, echocardiography shows no pericardial effusion here. Moreover, myocarditis commonly manifests with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, myalgia), new evidence of cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., sinus tachycardia, concave ST-segment elevations), and chest pain. Finally, this diagnosis is not consistent with the findings of macroglossia, anemia, and elevated serum creatinine.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm
- Heart rate approx. 65/min
- Normal heart axis (R > S in I and aVF)
- PR-interval duration approx. 120–160 ms
- Narrow QRS complex (approx. 100 ms)
- Concave ST elevations from a descending R wave in leads II, aVF, and V5–V6
- ST elevation (I and V4)

Unlike myocardial infarction, perimyocarditis does not manifest with ST elevations that correspond with the anatomy of coronary arteries.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of heart failure (dyspnea, JVD, peripheral and pulmonary edema), low-voltage QRS complexes on ECG, and symmetrical wall thickening with reduced diastolic filling on echocardiography, all of which are consistent with restrictive cardiomyopathy. The combination of restrictive cardiomyopathy and macroglossia suggests AL amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of worsening shortness of breath when lying down and lower leg swelling. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, and myocardial infarction that developed 10 years ago. Current medications include metoprolol, lisinopril, ethacrynic acid, eplerenone, and aspirin. He drinks one beer daily. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. He is allergic to sulfonamides. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention and 3+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Crackles are heard over the lower lung fields bilaterally. The point of maximal impulse is palpated 2 cm to the left of the midclavicular line at the 6th intercostal space. Which of the following additional findings is most strongly associated with increased mortality?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with CHF, low levels of brain natriuretic peptide are associated with a good prognosis. High BNP levels are associated with a poor prognosis.

B) CORRECT:

Under normal conditions, ADH secretion is tightly controlled by serum osmolality. But in patients with CHF, nonosmotic stimuli for ADH secretion (e.g., increased baroreceptor firing) become more relevant, and ADH secretion increases due to the decrease in cardiac output (CO). Increased ADH leads to increased reabsorption of free water, which, in turn, results in hyponatremia due to fluid dilution in the extracellular fluid compartment. A decrease in serum sodium is therefore closely associated with a decrease in CO in patients with heart failure.

Both diuretics and ACE inhibitors can cause hyponatremia but they are still recommended for patients with CHF because they increase free water elimination and improve cardiac function.

C) INCORRECT:

A narrow QRS complex (shorter than 120 ms) is a normal finding that is not associated with a poor prognosis. In patients with CHF, a wide QRS complex (> 120 ms) is associated with a poor prognosis because it indicates left and/or right bundle branch block, and the greater the duration of the QRS complex, the lower the left ventricular ejection fraction.

D) INCORRECT:

A decreased VO2 indicates a poor prognosis because it indicates poor cardiopulmonary reserves. Increased VO2 levels would not be expected in patients with CHF.

E) INCORRECT:

A high cardiac index is associated with a good prognosis in patients with CHF.

F) INCORRECT:

In patients with CHF, decreased beat-to-beat variation in heart rate (not increased) is associated with a poor prognosis because it signifies sympathetic overactivity.
questions.hint: This patient has signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure (CHF), which can result in increased fluid retention. An increase in fluid retention is associated with a poor prognosis.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician with a 9-month history of worsening shortness of breath on exertion and the need to urinate at night. He occasionally has palpitations but does not have chest pain. The patient had a transient ischemic attack 5 years ago for which he underwent right-sided carotid endarterectomy. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, aspirin, and simvastatin. He appears fatigued. His pulse is 61/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows cold extremities. There are no murmurs or rubs on cardiac auscultation. Fine, bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. There is 2+ lower extremity edema. An ECG shows sinus rhythm and T wave inversions in leads V1 to V4. Which of the following agents is most likely to improve the patient's long-term survival?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRAs), such as eplerenone, are associated with improved prognosis (i.e., reduced morbidity, mortality, and hospitalization rates) in patients with HF. MRAs are indicated for patients with ACC/AHA stage C HFrEF without contraindications (i.e., eGFR < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 and serum K+ > 5.0 mEq/L). Other drugs that improve prognosis in patients with HF include beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitors (ARNIs), hydralazine with isosorbide nitrate, and SGLT2 inhibitors.

This patient should be switched from lisinopril (an ACE inhibitor) to an ARNI (ARNIs are associated with a greater reduction in mortality and hospitalization rates), and a beta blocker should be added to maximize medical therapy. Beta blockers should be used with caution in the acute management of HF as they can worsen the condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker with no direct effect or survival benefit in patients with CHF. However, it can be used in this patient population for management of comorbidities such as resistant hypertension and/or angina despite maximal medical therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Ivabradine is a selective sinus node funny (If) channel inhibitor used in CHF patients with an LVEF < 35%, sinus rhythm, and resting heart rate ≥ 70 (this patient's heart rate is < 70). It is also indicated in symptomatic patients on maximum doses of or with contraindications to beta blockers. While ivabradine reduces the risk of hospitalization and mortality due to CHF, this patient does not meet the criteria for initiation of this agent.

D) INCORRECT:

Dobutamine is an inotropic agent that is not used in the long-term management of CHF. Instead, it can be used temporarily in patients with severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction and low cardiac output resulting in organ hypoperfusion. It has a role in severely ill patients with cardiogenic shock as a bridge to definitive therapy of the underlying cardiac condition (e.g., coronary revascularization therapy for myocardial infarction, heart transplantation).

E) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic used for symptomatic treatment in patients with CHF. While this patient with worsening shortness of breath, signs of pulmonary edema (fine crackles at the lung bases), and lower extremity edema would benefit from furosemide to improve his breathing, oxygenation, and volume overload status, furosemide has not been shown to improve survival in patients with CHF.

F) INCORRECT:

Verapamil is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker with negative inotropic effects. It can be used for rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation. There are no proven clinical or survival benefits in patients with CHF.

G) INCORRECT:

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that can be used for symptomatic treatment in patients with atrial fibrillation and CHF. While digoxin has been shown to reduce the rate of hospitalizations in patients with CHF, it has not been shown to improve overall survival.
questions.hint: This patient shows clinical signs of heart failure (HF), including progressively worsening exertional dyspnea, nocturia, cold extremities, and edema. The patient had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago, which is a strong risk factor for ischemic heart disease.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of worsening bouts of shortness of breath at night. He has had a cough for 1 month occasionally productive of frothy sputum. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and long-standing hypertension. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with Paget disease of bone during a routine health maintenance examination. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 145/98 mm Hg. Current medications include metformin, alendronate, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Physical examination shows bibasilar crackles. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched sound during late diastole that is best heard at the apex. There is no jugular venous distention or peripheral edema. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.46


PCO2

29 mm Hg


PO2

83 mm Hg


HCO3-

20 mEq/L


Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Destruction of alveolar walls is the pathophysiologic hallmark of emphysema, a subtype of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which would match the history of long-term smoking, shortness of breath, and productive cough. But for COPD, reduced lung sounds would be expected on auscultation. In addition, COPD would not explain this patient's S4 heart sound. Lastly, the CO2 retention that is associated with COPD leads to respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased myocardial contractility is the pathophysiologic mechanism of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), which commonly occurs after myocardial infarction (MI) or due to dilated cardiomyopathy. However, this patient's cardiac output is preserved, as is evident in his LVEF of 55%. In addition, despite this patient having risk factors for coronary artery disease (diabetes mellitus, hypertension, older age), he has no clinical features or history to suggest an MI.
Image Description:

Reduced cardiac output results in the activation of compensatory mechanisms (i.e., ADH and BNP production, activation of the renin-angiotensin system and sympathetic nervous system) in an attempt to restore cardiac output.

Cardiac remodeling and increases in afterload both have a negative effect on cardiac output. Increases in heart rate and preload have a positive effect on cardiac output. The net effect of these compensatory mechanisms may be sufficient to restore cardiac output. If not, the cycle repeats.

C) INCORRECT:

Diuretic overdose manifests as a contraction alkalosis characterized by volume depletion, which in turn activates the RAAS system. The renal changes caused by the aldosterone effect in the renal tubule (sodium reabsorption, potassium and hydrogen excretion) result in metabolic alkalosis, not respiratory alkalosis. Additionally, this patient does not have notable signs of volume depletion like thirst, decreased skin turgor, or dry mucous membranes.

D) INCORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration is the most common pathophysiologic cause of mitral valve prolapse (MVP). Although severe MVP could eventually lead to heart failure and pulmonary venous congestion due to increased left atrial pressure, this patient does not have typical features of MVP like chest pain, palpitations, and a high-frequency, midsystolic click that is best heard in the mitral region.

E) INCORRECT:

Because this patient was recently diagnosed with Paget disease of the bone, he is at increased risk of developing systemic arteriovenous fistulas, which can result in high output cardiac failure. This rare complication is caused by the increased vascularity within the abnormal bone that is undergoing high rates of remodeling. High-output cardiac failure manifests with features of hyperdynamic circulation such as high pulse pressure, bounding pulses with a quick upstroke, subungual capillary pulsations, and venous hums, none of which is present in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Chronic uncontrolled hypertension is the most common cause of HFpEF. Chronic hypertension increases the afterload against which the left ventricle (LV) contracts. As a compensatory mechanism, the myocardium undergoes concentric hypertrophy to maintain cardiac output. Over time, the compensatory response of LV thickening is associated with the maladaptive change of interstitial myocardial fibrosis, which leads to an increase in LV stiffness and impaired myocardial relaxation. As a result, patients develop an increase in left ventricular filling pressures and reduced ventricular filling with normal ventricular contraction (i.e., diastolic dysfunction). Severe myocardial fibrosis can ultimately impair myocardial contractility and result in systolic dysfunction but in such a scenario, the patient will have a low ejection fraction.

Note that impaired myocardial relaxation could have also been correct for restrictive cardiomyopathy, in which the ventricular walls harden without myocardial hypertrophy.
questions.hint: This patient has features of acute left heart failure, including paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, a cough productive of frothy sputum, an S4 heart sound (low frequency, late diastolic sound) and bibasilar crackles (suggesting pulmonary edema), and a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 55%, all of which are consistent with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). The ABG shows compensated primary respiratory alkalosis, likely due to hyperventilation.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of shortness of breath with exertion. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include aspirin, losartan, simvastatin, and insulin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 150/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Cardiac examination is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
Video

choices.text: Earlier onset of abnormal cardiac sound with standing
Elevated serum brain natriuretic peptide levels
Left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Earlier onset of abnormal cardiac sound with standing is an auscultatory finding in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP). It is caused by a decrease in preload, which is due to pooling of blood in the venous system. This, in turn, decreases both right and left ventricular volume, resulting in decreased tension and prolapse of the valve. MVP manifests with a high-frequency, midsystolic click that is best heard at the mitral region, which is not consistent with this patient's auscultation findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the aortic valve is the most common cause of aortic stenosis (AS). The resulting left ventricular outflow tract obstruction causes left ventricular hypertrophy, which manifests with an S4 gallop, not an S3 gallop. Moreover, the murmur that is characteristic of aortic stenosis is a systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard loudest at the upper right sternal border, which this patient does not have.

C) CORRECT:

Elevated levels of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and the presence of an S3 gallop both indicate increased ventricular filling pressures, which is seen in heart failure (HF). BNP, which is released in response to stretching of the cardiac ventricle, is a sensitive parameter to evaluate patients with symptoms of HF. High levels of BNP (> 400 pg/mL) in patients with classic symptoms of HF have a high positive predictive value and are associated with a worse prognosis, while low values (< 100 pg/mL) in patients with dyspnea have a high negative predictive value for HF.

D) INCORRECT:

Digital clubbing is primarily seen in patients with pulmonary diseases that result in chronic hypoxemia, such as cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis, interstitial lung disease, and non-small cell lung cancer. It may also be seen in cyanotic heart disease and infectious endocarditis, which are unlikely diagnoses in a 66-year-old afebrile patient. As clubbing is a nonspecific physical finding, it is unlikely to help pinpoint the diagnosis. While shortness of breath can be of pulmonary origin, this patient's S3 gallop on examination is more concerning for a cardiac cause.

E) INCORRECT:

A left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum is the pathophysiologic mechanism of an atrial septal defect (ASD). Auscultatory findings in ASD include a systolic ejection murmur over the left upper sternal border (due to increased blood flow across the pulmonary valve), a diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (due to increased blood flow across the tricuspid valve), and a fixed, widely split S2, none of which are seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Bounding pulses of peripheral arteries (water hammer pulse) occur in patients with aortic regurgitation (AR) and are caused by the hemodynamic changes caused by the regurgitant aortic valve. While an S3 gallop can occur in AR, this patient lacks the characteristic decrescendo, early diastolic murmur of AR, which is best heard in the left third and fourth intercostal spaces along the left sternal border.

G) INCORRECT:

Rupture of a papillary muscle would result in acute mitral regurgitation (MR), a complication associated with myocardial infarction (MI). While this patient has several risk factors for MI, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus, he has no symptoms of chest pain or signs to suggest ongoing acute coronary syndrome. Additionally, this patient lacks the characteristic holosystolic, blowing murmur of MR, which is best heard in the apex.
questions.hint: This patient's cardiac examination reveals a third heart sound (S3 gallop).

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fatigue, worsening abdominal discomfort, and progressive swelling of his legs for 3 months. The swelling is worse in the evenings. His only medication is ibuprofen for occasional joint pain. The patient does not smoke and drinks 2–3 beers each weekend. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows a mildly distended abdomen with shifting dullness. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin. When pressure is applied to the right upper quadrant, the patient's jugular veins become visibly distended for 15 seconds. The 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands are tender to palpation. There is 2+ edema in the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's edema?

choices.text: Impaired relaxation of the right ventricle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired albumin synthesis due to chronic hepatocellular injury can be seen in cirrhosis. Liver cirrhosis commonly manifests with bilateral pitting edema and ascites, as a result of hypoalbuminemia, as seen here. However, affected individuals are expected to present with further stigmata of chronic liver disease at advanced stages, including a shrunken liver (especially in advanced stages), rather than hepatomegaly. Further, this patient presents with symmetric arthropathy of the 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal joints, a feature suggestive of hemochromatosis. Although hemochromatosis is a common etiology of cirrhosis, this patient's positive HJR cannot be explained by hepatic disease.

B) CORRECT:

Assessing HJR can help distinguish cardiac disease from hepatic disease in a patient presenting with bilateral lower extremity edema and ascites. A positive HJR indicates impaired relaxation of the right ventricle and consequent inability to accommodate an increased venous return to the heart. The most common causes of this finding include restrictive cardiomyopathy, constrictive pericarditis, and right ventricular heart failure (e.g., due to myocardial infarction). This patient further presents with features suggestive of hemochromatosis: symmetric arthropathy of the 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal joints, fatigue, abdominal pain, and hepatomegaly. These findings indicate that he has restrictive cardiomyopathy as a result of iron deposition in the heart, which ultimately causes congestive hepatopathy (cardiac cirrhosis).

C) INCORRECT:

A reduced glomerular filtration rate is seen in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). Lower extremity edema and ascites are possible findings in patients with CKD (due to proteinuria), but such a diagnosis is unlikely in this patient without risk factors for kidney disease (e.g., diabetes mellitus, chronic hypertension). Hepatomegaly might be present if CKD is a result of liver cirrhosis (hepatorenal syndrome), although a shrunken liver is a more common finding, and further stigmata of chronic liver disease would be expected. Moreover, this patient's positive HJR cannot be explained by renal or hepatic disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis caused by viral infection of hepatocytes can manifest with fatigue, arthralgia, hepatomegaly, and abdominal discomfort, as seen in this patient. In advanced disease, lower extremity edema and ascites may occur due to cirrhosis. However, affected individuals are expected to present with further stigmata of chronic liver disease at advanced stages. Moreover, this patient's positive HJR cannot be explained by hepatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Dermal deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the skin and other tissues presenting as nonpitting edema is seen in patients with myxedema coma, a rare complication of severe hypothyroidism. While this patient's fatigue might raise concerns for hypothyroidism, features such as hepatomegaly, ascites, and positive HJR cannot be explained by hypothyroidism or myxedema coma.

F) INCORRECT:

Macrovesicular steatosis of the liver is seen in alcohol fatty liver as well as in non-alcoholic steatohepatitis. These conditions can manifest with hepatomegaly and abdominal discomfort, as seen here. However, ascites and peripheral edema are expected only after progression to cirrhosis, at which point further stigmata of chronic liver disease would be expected. Moreover, this patient's positive HJR cannot be explained by hepatic disease.
questions.hint: This patient has a positive hepatojugular reflux (HJR).

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of worsening nocturia, fatigue, and shortness of breath on exertion. While he used to be able to walk for 15 minutes at a time, he now has to pause every 5 minutes. Recently, he has started using two pillows to avoid waking up short of breath at night. He has a history of hypertension treated with daily amlodipine and prazosin; he has difficulty adhering to his medication regimen. His pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a laterally displaced apical heartbeat and 2+ bilateral pitting edema of the lower legs. Auscultation shows an S4 gallop and fine bibasilar rales. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following pathophysiologic changes in this patient?

choices.text: Decrease in total peripheral vascular resistance

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The reduced cardiac output seen in CHF results in organ hypoperfusion, which also affects the kidneys. Renal hypoperfusion leads to compensatory activation of RAAS in order to maintain the GFR. Angiotensin II causes vasoconstriction of the afferent and efferent arterioles within the kidney, decreasing the net renal blood flow. Vasoconstriction is more pronounced in the efferent arteriole, which results in an increase in intraglomerular pressure to maintain GFR. In combination with the other effects of RAAS activation (aldosterone-induced renal Na+/H2O resorption and systemic vasoconstriction), this maintains cardiac output.

Although RAAS activation is a compensatory mechanism for maintaining cardiac output in patients with CHF, prolonged renal hypoperfusion (particularly in conjunction with precipitating factors, such as NSAID use and dehydration) can lead to renal dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

An increase in bicarbonate excretion can be a compensatory mechanism in patients with respiratory alkalosis or a cause of metabolic acidosis, e.g., in type 2 acute tubular acidosis. This patient presents with CHF, which would not result in increased bicarbonate excretion. Instead, elevated aldosterone levels due to upregulation of RAAS lead to an increase in renal sodium resorption in exchange for both hydrogen and potassium. This would cause a net loss of hydrogen in the urine. For this reason, patients with CHF are prone to developing metabolic alkalosis.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with CHF, which is characterized by reduced cardiac output and activation of the sympathetic system and RAAS. This compensatory mechanism results in systemic vasoconstriction, which increases rather than decreases systemic vascular resistance.

D) INCORRECT:

Elastance (E = pressure/volume) is the reciprocal value of compliance (C = 1/E = volume/pressure), the more commonly used concept to evaluate the relationship between transported volume and applied pressure. An increase in left ventricular compliance is seen in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy (eccentric hypertrophy), which results in systolic dysfunction. This patient, however, presents with CHF that is most likely due to chronic hypertension, as suggested by his history of poor compliance with his medication regimen. Chronic hypertension results predominantly in concentric ventricular hypertrophy, which leads to decreased left ventricular compliance (as indicated by the S4 gallop seen here) and diastolic dysfunction. This translates to an increased left ventricular elastance.

E) INCORRECT:

Surfactant ensures low alveolar surface tension to prevent alveolar collapse. This patient has signs of pulmonary edema, which is characterized by fluid accumulation within the pulmonary interstitium and alveoli. This, in turn, causes increased (not decreased) alveolar surface tension, which results in alveolar collapse that causes dyspnea, decreased exercise capacity, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, as seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

An increase in potassium retention occurs secondary to hypoaldosteronism. However, this patient presents with CHF, characterized by reduced cardiac output and organ hypoperfusion, which also affects the kidneys. Reduced renal blood flow results in RAAS activation. This patient is therefore more likely to have elevated aldosterone levels, resulting in increased renal Na+ and H2O resorption as well as potassium excretion.
questions.hint: This patient has classic signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure (CHF), including dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, nocturia, bibasilar rales from pulmonary edema (suggestive of left-sided heart failure), and pitting edema (suggestive of right-sided heart failure). CHF is characterized by reduced cardiac output, which activates numerous compensatory neurohumoral mechanisms.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-week history of shortness of breath and dull chest pain. She has a history of antiphospholipid syndrome. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. Right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 30 mm Hg and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Constriction of the renal afferent arteriole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In cases of systemic hypoperfusion, reduced renal perfusion results in dilatation of the afferent arteriole via myogenic autoregulation and the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism, as well as constriction of the efferent arteriole via an increase in angiotensin II synthesis. Afferent arteriole dilation and efferent arteriole constriction then work in combination to maintain a constant GFR despite decreased cardiac output. Right heart failure is a condition that can cause systemic hypoperfusion. For this reason dilatation (not constriction) of the renal afferent arteriole would rather be expected in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Right heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension involves increased afterload of the right ventricle, resulting in reduced right ventricular output. Reduced right-sided cardiac output leads to venous congestion in the vessels that drain into the right heart, including the coronary sinus, which can become dilated as a result.
Image Description:

The coronary sinus is the largest vein of the heart. It lies in the left posterior atrioventricular groove and opens into the right atrium.

Main tributaries of the coronary sinus:
- Great cardiac vein: lies in the left anterior atrioventricular groove; receives the anterior interventricular vein that begins at the cardiac apex
- Small cardiac vein: lies in the right posterior atrioventricular groove; receives the right marginal vein and the anterior veins of the right ventricle
- Middle cardiac vein: lies in the posterior interventricular groove
- Posterior vein(s) of the left ventricle: lies to the left of the middle cardiac vein

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased left ventricular contractility is the hallmark of systolic left heart failure. Although left heart failure can lead to right heart failure, PCWP is typically elevated in left heart failure (> 18 mm Hg). This patient's normal PCWP makes left heart failure unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve leaflet thickening can occur in mitral valve diseases such as mitral stenosis (e.g., due to rheumatic fever). Mitral valve disease usually results in increased left atrial pressure and therefore increased PCWP, whereas PCWP is normal in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (heart failure cells) are typically seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary congestion due to blood leakage into the alveolar spaces. Conditions that cause chronic pulmonary venous congestion include left heart failure and mitral stenosis. PCWP is typically elevated in left heart failure and mitral stenosis, whereas it is normal in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Accumulations of hemosiderin-laden macrophages, known as siderophages (examples indicated by blue overlay), are visible within alveoli. Additionally, alveoli filled with erythrocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen.

Siderophages in pulmonary alveoli (heart failure cells) suggest decompensated heart failure.
questions.hint: The presence of jugular venous distention suggests right heart failure, which can manifest with findings such as exertional shortness of breath and chest pain, as seen here. Antiphospholipid syndrome can cause pulmonary embolism, resulting in pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. A mean pulmonary artery pressure ≥ 25 mm Hg at rest confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension, and a normal PCWP (4–12 mm Hg) excludes left heart failure as the cause.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening shortness of breath on exertion and bouts of coughing while sleeping. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, simvastatin, and insulin. The patient appears tired but in no acute distress. His pulse is 70/min, blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg, and respirations are 25/min. He has crackles over both lower lung fields and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. An ECG shows T wave inversions in leads V1 to V4. Which of the following agents is most likely to improve the patient's long-term survival?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is used for symptomatic treatment in patients with CHF. While this patient with exertional dyspnea, fine, bilateral crackles at the lung bases, and lower extremity edema would benefit from furosemide to improve his breathing, oxygenation, and volume overload status, furosemide has not been associated with improved survival in patients with CHF.

B) INCORRECT:

Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that can be used in treating hypertriglyceridemia. Fibrates as a drug class are not known to improve survival in heart failure. Furthermore, this patient already takes simvastatin: the addition of fibrates would greatly increase his risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis.

C) CORRECT:

Beta blockers, such as metoprolol, should be avoided in patients with decompensated heart failure because the negative inotropic and chronotropic effects of these drugs could decrease cardiac output and worsen symptoms. However, beta blockers improve survival in patients with chronic compensated heart failure because these effects decrease myocardial oxygen demand. Beta blockers also reduce the risks of chronic exposure to catecholamines and prevent myocardial remodeling. These drugs should therefore be initiated once a patient with heart failure is stabilized.

Other drugs that improve survival in patients with heart failure include ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitors, aldosterone antagonists, hydralazine with nitrate, and SGLT2 inhibitors. Diuretics and digoxin improve symptoms of CHF and significantly reduce the frequency of hospitalization but do not significantly improve prognosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Digoxin is indicated for patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and persistent symptoms despite treatment with first-line medications. Although digoxin reduces symptoms and lowers the risk of hospitalization, it does not improve overall survival.

E) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB) that can be added to the medication regimen of hypertensive patients who do not fully respond to initial therapy such as this man (hypertension despite lisinopril). However, CCBs have not been shown to have a direct effect or survival benefit in patients with CHF.

F) INCORRECT:

Dobutamine is an inotropic agent that can be used temporarily in patients with severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction and low cardiac output resulting in organ hypoperfusion. It has a role in severely ill patients with cardiogenic shock as a bridge to definitive therapy of the underlying cardiac condition (coronary revascularization therapy for MI, heart transplantation, among others). Dobutamine is not used chronically for management of CHF.
questions.hint: Exertional dyspnea, nocturnal cough, crackles on auscultation (suggesting pulmonary edema), peripheral edema, and T wave inversions on ECG (suggesting structural myocardial damage) are consistent with congestive heart failure (CHF).

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being stabbed in the left thigh. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm wound overlying a pulsatile mass on the left anterior thigh, 4 cm below the inguinal crease. A thrill is palpated, and a bruit is heard over this area. Peripheral pulses are normal bilaterally. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The aneurysmal dilation of an arteriovenous fistula in the anterior thigh 4 cm below the inguinal crease can result in compression of surrounding structures. However, pudendal nerve compression is unlikely given the location of this patient's injury.

B) CORRECT:

High-output cardiac failure can occur following the formation of a traumatic arteriovenous fistula due to the shunting of blood from the arterial high-pressure system to the venous low-pressure system. As a result of this shunt, systemic vascular resistance decreases, which, in turn, results in an increased heart rate, stroke volume, and cardiac output. However, despite increased cardiac output, low systemic vascular resistance results in arterial underfilling, decreased renal perfusion, and retention of water and salt, which leads to volume overload and heart failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has an increased risk of thrombus development at the site of an arteriovenous fistula, a pulmonary embolism would be an unlikely complication because a dislodged thrombus would travel distally into the affected vein as a result of the reverse blood flow caused by the pressure differential from the arterial to venous systems.

D) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for the development of an iliac artery aneurysm include connective tissue disorders, older age, history of smoking, hypertension, and atherosclerosis. The mechanism of this patient's injury could compromise the vascular integrity at the level of the injury but is unlikely to affect the iliac artery given how distal the wound is.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteonecrosis of the femoral head can result from trauma to the medial circumflex femoral artery (e.g., from femoral head fracture or lateral or medial femoral neck fracture, especially with dislocation). However, a stab wound in the anterior thigh is unlikely to affect the medial circumflex femoral artery.
questions.hint: This patient has a traumatic arteriovenous fistula, which typically manifests as a pulsatile mass with a palpable thrill and audible bruit.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with coronary artery disease comes to the emergency department because of chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 3 hours. Troponin levels are elevated and an ECG shows ST-elevations in the precordial leads. Revascularization with percutaneous coronary intervention is performed, and a stent is successfully placed in the left anterior descending artery. Two days later, he complains of worsening shortness of breath. Pulse oximetry on 3L of nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. An x-ray of the chest shows distended pulmonary veins, small horizontal lines at the lung bases, and blunting of the costophrenic angles bilaterally. Which of the following findings would be most likely on a ventilation-perfusion scan of this patient?

choices.text: Increased apical ventilation with normal perfusion bilaterally
Normal ventilation with multiple, bilateral perfusion defects
Normal perfusion with bilateral ventilation defects
Normal perfusion with decreased ventilation at the right base

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A high apical ventilation-perfusion ratio is a physiologic finding in healthy lungs under resting conditions. At baseline, the lung apices receive less perfusion due to gravity, resulting in a V/Q ratio of around 3 in those areas. In situations of high oxygen demand (e.g., physical exercise), apical perfusion can be increased. This patient, however, shows signs of pulmonary edema.

B) INCORRECT:

The pattern of normal ventilation with multiple perfusion defects can be seen in patients with pulmonary emboli. Blood clots obstruct lung arteries and subsequently cause decreased perfusion. As there is no airway obstruction, ventilation is maintained. This patient's dyspnea could indicate pulmonary embolism. However, his x-ray findings and the history of a recent myocardial infarction suggests pulmonary edema.

C) INCORRECT:

A matched ventilation-perfusion ratio bilaterally (e.g., V/Q = 1) can be seen with either decrease in both ventilation and perfusion or increase in both ventilation and perfusion. Bilateral increase in V/Q can be seen with exercise, during which there is physiologic vasodilation of the apical capillaries, resulting in increased perfusion of the apices with matched ventilation. A bilateral decrease in both ventilation and perfusion can be seen in patients with emphysema due to the destruction of both the alveoli and the capillary bed. Other possibilities include the combination of two separate conditions, of which one causes alveolar hypoventilation (e.g., opioid intoxication) and the other causes pulmonary hypoperfusion (e.g., right-sided heart failure, severe hypotension). This patient shows signs of pulmonary edema, which would present with different findings.

D) CORRECT:

Areas with normal perfusion and no ventilation (ventilation-perfusion mismatch) are seen in patients with pulmonary edema. Elevated pulmonary venous pressures (secondary to decreased left ventricular function) results in increased amounts of intra-alveolar fluid, which leads to impaired alveolar ventilation. Insufficiently oxygenated blood from parts of the lungs that are not ventilated mixes with oxygenated blood from ventilated parts of the lungs, resulting in an overall decrease in PaO2, increased A-a gradient, and systemic hypoxemia.

Other conditions that can result in ventilation-perfusion mismatch include pneumonia (impaired ventilation) and pulmonary embolism (impaired perfusion).
Image Description:

Pathologic lung conditions can alter V/Q ratios.

Decreased ventilation leads to shunt perfusion (wasted perfusion) and a low V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no ventilation left (V = 0), V/Q ratio equals zero.

Decreased perfusion leads to dead space ventilation (wasted ventilation) and a high V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no perfusion left (Q = 0), V/Q ratio equals infinity.

E) INCORRECT:

Normal perfusion with focal areas of decreased ventilation can be caused by localized inflammatory processes, such as pneumonia, bronchial obstruction, or malignancy. Patients with pneumonia have increased intra-alveolar fluid in some parts of the lungs, causing a decreased ventilation of those areas. This patient's dyspnea could be a sign of pneumonia but his x-ray findings and the history of a recent myocardial infarction suggest pulmonary edema.
questions.hint: The combination of a recent myocardial infarction, worsening dyspnea, and chest x-ray findings showing pulmonary vein congestion, Kerley B lines, and pleural effusions should raise suspicion for cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

questions.text: An investigator is studying patients with acute decompensated congestive heart failure. He takes measurements of a hormone released from atrial myocytes, as well as serial measurements of left atrial and left ventricular pressures. The investigator observes a positive correlation between left atrial pressures and the serum level of this hormone. Which of the following is most likely the mechanism of action of this hormone?

choices.text: Decreases sodium reabsorption at the collecting tubules
Increases potassium excretion at the collecting ducts
Decreases reabsorption of bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubules
Increases free water reabsorption from the distal tubules

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

ANP dilates the afferent arterioles and constricts the efferent arterioles, which increases glomerular filtration rate by increasing the net filtration pressure. Moreover, ANP decreases sodium reabsorption in the principal cells of the collecting tubule. Using these two mechanisms, ANP promotes natriuresis in response to increased stretch on the atrial lumen in an attempt to reduce the impact of volume overload. While atrial myocytes release ANP upon stretching, ventricular myocytes liberate BNP, which has a similar effect but lasts longer than ANP. Hence, BNP and NT-pro BNP levels are important serum markers for the diagnosis of CHF.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased potassium excretion at the collecting ducts occurs with hyperaldosteronism. Aldosterone increases extracellular fluid. In these patients, however, this mechanism would worsen cardiac congestion. In this patient, ANP is released, which decreases potassium excretion.

C) INCORRECT:

Constriction of afferent arterioles decreases renal blood flow and thereby reduces glomerular filtration rate (GFR), which then reduces urine output and worsens congestion in patients with CHF exacerbations. In contrast, the release of ANP in this patient attempts to compensate volume overload by stimulating afferent arteriole dilation and promoting natriuresis.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased reabsorption of bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) leads to urine alkalinization and causes mild diuresis. Although this might moderately decrease congestion in patients with CHF, this does not describe the mechanism of action of the ANP released in this patient. It does, however, describe the MOA of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide).

E) INCORRECT:

Increased free water reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) is mediated by the antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which is released in response to decreased atrial pressure. This investigator observes serum concentration of ANP, which increases diuresis by inhibiting sodium reabsorption. ANP does not play a role in regulating free water reabsorption. Moreover, increased free water reabsorption would worsen congestion in patients with CHF exacerbations.
questions.hint: Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) is a hormone released from the atrial myocytes in response to increased stretch on the atrial lumen, especially in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF) exacerbations.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of epigastric pain, sweating, and breathlessness for 45 minutes. She has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks 1 glass of wine daily. Her pulse is 105/min and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.49


pCO2

32 mm Hg


pO2

57 mm Hg


An ECG shows ST elevations in leads V1–V6. Which of the following is the most likely cause of hypoxemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased transpulmonary pressure can result from a pneumothorax, which also manifests with similar ABG findings, dyspnea, and tachycardia, as observed in this patient. In addition, this woman's long-term smoking history increases her risk of spontaneous pneumothorax. However, epigastric pain is not typically associated with pneumothorax. In addition, this patient's ECG results are not consistent with a pneumothorax.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased minute ventilation can be seen in patients with depression in the respiratory center of the brain (e.g., opioid overdose) and in those with impairment of the peripheral nerves or respiratory muscles. A slow breathing rate and/or low tidal volume results in hypoxemia, as seen on this patient’s ABG. However, CO2 would also accumulate, causing hypoxic hypercapnic respiratory acidosis, as opposed to the respiratory alkalosis present here.

C) CORRECT:

Increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure can occur in the setting of myocardial infarction (MI) due to cardiogenic shock. An extensive myocardial infarction, as seen in this patient, may result in decreased cardiac contractility and reduced cardiac output, leading to increased left-sided heart pressures and ultimately backup of blood to the lungs. Cardiogenic pulmonary edema thickens the alveolar-capillary membrane and impairs oxygen diffusion capacity. As a compensatory mechanism, minute ventilation increases, resulting in increased CO2 elimination. This patient's inability to oxygenate with preserved ventilation, as reflected by the hypoxemia without concurrent hypercapnia in her arterial blood gas analysis, is consistent with type 1 respiratory failure.

This patient shows an atypical presentation of myocardial infarction, which is more likely to occur in patients who are older, female, and/or have diabetes mellitus. These patients can present with minimal or no chest pain while autonomic symptoms are often the chief complaint. When evaluating patients with symptoms like epigastric pain, sweating, and breathlessness, acute coronary syndrome is an important differential diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased total body hemoglobin (Hb) can result from acute blood loss in the setting of a ruptured aortic aneurysm (AA). A ruptured AA can manifest with tachycardia, hypotension, dyspnea, sweating, and abdominal pain, as seen in this patient. Risk factors include a history of hypertension and smoking, both of which are present here. However, patients with AA classically present with severe, tearing pain in the chest, back, and/or abdomen. Additionally, though decreased Hb results in a decreased O2 delivery to tissue (hypoxia), it would not explain this patient’s decreased pO2 (hypoxemia) on ABG or the ST elevations on ECG.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased pulmonary capillary permeability is seen in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). ARDS manifests with similar ABG findings, sweating, and dyspnea, which are seen in this patient. A known cause of ARDS is acute pancreatitis, a condition that manifests with epigastric pain and is associated with chronic alcohol use. However, this patient only drinks one glass of wine per day, making acute pancreatitis, and therefore ARDS, unlikely. Finally, this patient's ECG results are not consistent with a diagnosis of ARDS.
questions.hint: This patient's multiple cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., hypertension and smoking history) in conjunction with epigastric pain, sweating, dyspnea, and tachycardia should raise concern for myocardial infarction. The ST elevations in the anterior leads are diagnostic of an extensive anterior myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His pulse is 96/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's acute onset dyspnea and CXR findings suggest cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to left ventricular failure. Individuals with left ventricular failure initially develop interstitial edema, which results in smooth reticular opacification and Kerley B lines due to accentuation of the vascular markings. With the further increase in pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, individuals can develop features of alveolar edema (e.g., consolidation with an air bronchogram) and pleural effusion (e.g., blunting of the costophrenic angle). In pulmonary edema, the opacification can often assume a perihilar distribution (a so-called “batwing” or “butterfly-shaped” pattern), which is seen here, because the periphery of the lung has better lymphatic drainage than the central regions.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation is a rare valvular condition. It typically manifests with clinical features of right heart failure, such as jugular venous distention, pulsatile hepatomegaly, and pedal edema, none of which are seen here. Moreover, the CXR findings for tricuspid regurgitation typically include right atrial and right ventricular enlargement, unlike the left ventricular enlargement seen on this patient's CXR.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a neonate with Ebstein anomaly

The cardiac silhouette is markedly enlarged. Prominent convexity of the right heart border (green line) is the result of caudal displacement of the tricuspid valve with atrialization of the right ventricle and tricuspid regurgitation. The central pulmonary arteries (green arrowheads) and aortic knob (red arrowhead) are diminutive in appearance. An endotracheal tube is present, along with an umbilical venous catheter and nasogastric tube.

Radiographic findings in Ebstein anomaly may vary with the severity of the condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous pneumothorax causes acute onset dyspnea, and a CXR would show a radiolucent region without lung markings (air collection). This patient's CXR findings are inconsistent with a pneumothorax.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient without a history of trauma

A large left pneumothorax (blue overlay) is seen, with an absence of lung markings peripheral to the collapsed lung (yellow overlay). Contralateral shift of the mediastinum (indicated by arrows) has resulted in a prominent right heart border (white line), and there is slight widening of the left lateral costophrenic angle (angle marker). These findings are consistent with tension pneumothorax. Incidentally noted is a mild rotatory curvature of the upper thoracic spine.

The absence of thoracic trauma suggests a spontaneous pneumothorax.

Dashed white line: visceral pleural line; green overlay: spinous process; red overlay: vertebral pedicles

D) INCORRECT:

Acute respiratory distress syndrome can cause dyspnea, and a CXR would show butterfly-shaped perihilar opacification, which is seen here. However, this patient's cardiomegaly suggests a chronic underlying cardiovascular condition and, thus, a cardiac cause for the pulmonary edema.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view) of a patient with adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

Confluent and multifocal airspace opacities (examples indicated by green overlay) predominate in the lower zones of the lungs. Air bronchograms (examples indicated by red lines) are visible in some locations. There are no Kerley lines or pleural effusions. The cardiac silhouette size is normal. An endotracheal tube (arrow) is present.

ARDS and other causes of noncardiogenic edema can produce extensive airspace opacification, as can cardiogenic edema, diffuse pneumonia, diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, pneumonic-type adenocarcinoma, and pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Radiography alone cannot establish a diagnosis of ARDS.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism can cause acute onset dyspnea as well as blunting of the costophrenic angle due to a pleural effusion caused by pulmonary infarction. Kerley B lines and butterfly-shaped perihilar opacities would not, however, be seen in pulmonary embolism. The CXR findings associated with pulmonary embolism are relatively nonsensitive and nonspecific and include wedge-shaped pulmonary opacification due to pulmonary infarction, a regional decrease in pulmonary vascular markings, and enlargement of the pulmonary artery, none of which are seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pleuritic chest pain

A peripheral opacity (Hampton hump; green overlay) obscures the adjacent margin of the right hemidiaphragm. A Hampton hump is subpleural and is caused by pulmonary hemorrhage or infarction. The appearance is often wedge-shaped; however, it can alternatively be dome-shaped, if the apex is spared as a result of collateral bronchial arterial blood flow.

The differential diagnosis includes pneumonia and malignancy. Of note, the greater distance between the spinous processes and the medial edge of the clavicle on the right compared to the left indicates that the patient is rotated slightly to the right. The distances will be nearly equal when a patient is not rotated, whereas widening will be seen on the side to which a patient is rotated.

Dashed lines: margins of medial clavicles; White line and ellipses: spinous processes

F) INCORRECT:

Smoking is an important risk factor for pulmonary emphysema, which causes dyspnea and fatigue. However, the symptoms of emphysema typically evolve over months and years rather than a few days. Moreover, the characteristic CXR findings for emphysema are increased lung lucency and flattening of the diaphragm due to hyperinflation. This patient's CXR findings are inconsistent with pulmonary emphysema.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of emphysema

The lungs are hyperlucent, with diaphragmatic flattening (indicated by dashed lines and arrows) and widening of the costophrenic sulci (indicated by white lines). The findings are consistent with air trapping.

An additional finding is asymmetry of the lung apices with slightly increased opacification in the left apex (red overlay) compared to the right. The chronicity cannot be determined from this single study, and the differential for chronic causes includes both scar and malignancy. A second small indeterminate opacity projects in the lower left lung (green overlay).

G) INCORRECT:

Certain infectious causes of interstitial pneumonia (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumonia, Pneumocystis pneumonia) lead to acute onset dyspnea, fatigue, and perihilar interstitial infiltrates. However, blunting of the costophrenic angle (due to pleural effusion) is uncommon in both Mycoplasma and Pneumocystis pneumonia, and features such as cardiomegaly and Kerley B lines would not be expected in interstitial pneumonia.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (A: PA view; B: lateral view) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

Bilateral airspace and interstitial opacities are predominant in the perihilar regions of both lungs, in the left greater than the right (examples indicated by green overlay). The heart size is normal and there are no pleural effusions.

H) INCORRECT:

An acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma can cause acute onset dyspnea, and the CXR would be normal or show evidence of hyperinflation (e.g., increased lung lucency, flattening of the diaphragm). This patient's CXR findings are inconsistent with bronchial asthma.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

Large lung volumes (green outline and arrows) are accompanied by intercostal space widening (examples indicated by red arrows) and diaphragmatic flattening, indicating hyperinflation.

I) INCORRECT:

Smoking is an important risk factor for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), which can cause dyspnea and reticular opacification. However, the symptoms of IPF typically evolve over months and years rather than a few days.
