In addition, the reticular opacification of IPF manifests with honeycombing of the lung, and it typically affects the base of the lungs, unlike the butterfly-shaped perihilar reticular opacities seen here. Moreover, the CXR findings of Kerley B lines and blunting of the costophrenic angle are inconsistent with IPF.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (posteroanterior view) of a patient with chronic progressive shortness of breath

Coarse reticular opacities (examples indicated by blue circles) in both lungs show a basal predominant distribution. The cardiac silhouette is enlarged and midline sternotomy wires (example of sternal wire indicated by black outline) and surgical clips (red lines) are evidence of prior coronary artery bypass grafting; however, there are no supportive findings for cardiogenic pulmonary edema, such as Kerley lines or pleural effusions.

CT was subsequently performed and showed peripheral honeycombing diagnostic of a usual-interstitial-pneumonia pattern. The patient was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (green overlay).
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray (CXR) shows butterfly-shaped perihilar opacification, Kerley B lines, cardiomegaly, and blunting of the costophrenic angle.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit for shortness of breath and palpitations. A cardiac catheterization is performed and measurements of the left ventricular volume and pressure at different points in the cardiac cycle are obtained. The patient's pressure-volume loop (light gray) is shown with a normal pressure-volume loop (dark gray) for comparison. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In mitral valve regurgitation (MR), the stroke volume is divided between the output through the aortic valve and through the abnormal regurgitant mitral valve, which results in reduced afterload (↓ outflow resistance) and decreased end-systolic volume (top left of the pressure-volume loop). This patient's pressure-volume loop also shows a decreased end-systolic volume but, in MR, there is an increase in left-ventricular end-diastolic volume (bottom right), which is not seen here. This ventricular volume overload results in increased preload, which increases the stroke volume (apparent in a pressure-volume loop that is widened, not narrowed). Moreover, there is no true isovolumetric contraction phase in MR.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased systemic vascular resistance (SVR) increases afterload, resulting in a pressure-volume loop that is taller and narrower than normal. The increased height reflects the fact that the left ventricle must reach a higher pressure to overcome the aortic pressure (so that the aortic valve opens), and, consequently, an end-systolic pressure that is higher than normal. The pressure-volume loop is narrower because the increased afterload from high SVR leads to a decreased stroke volume.

C) CORRECT:

Increased ventricular wall stiffness decreases ventricular compliance, which is the underlying cause of diastolic dysfunction. Stiffening of the ventricles results in impaired diastolic filling, while ejection fraction (and thus, systolic function) is (for the most part) preserved. The slope of the end-diastolic pressure-volume curve (the bottom line of the pressure-volume loop) is the inverse of the ventricular compliance, which is decreased in this patient. The narrowed pressure-volume loop shows a decreased stroke volume, which is also classically seen in heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). Patients typically present with signs and symptoms of heart failure (e.g., shortness of breath, jugular venous distention) and an S4 atrial gallop, which is caused by contraction of the atria against the noncompliant ventricles.

Causes of HFpEF include concentric left ventricular hypertrophy secondary to hypertension (most common cause), restrictive cardiomyopathy (most commonly due to amyloidosis), and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Image Description:

The pressure-volume (P-V) loop in systolic dysfunction (yellow): Loss of contractility in systolic dysfunction reduces the slope of the line depicting the end-systolic P-V relationship. Therefore, the end-systolic volume (top left corner of P-V loop) appears increased compared to the normal P-V loop (green). The end-diastolic volume (bottom right corner of P-V loop) is also increased because of normal venous return to a high end-systolic volume. This higher end-diastolic volume partially increases the stroke volume via the Frank-Starling mechanism.

The P-V loop in diastolic dysfunction (blue): Increased stiffness of the ventricle in diastolic dysfunction means that the line depicting the diastolic P-V curve is shifted upwards and to the left. For any given diastolic volume, the ventricular pressure is higher in a dysfunctional heart compared to a healthy heart (green loop), and the end-diastolic volume is reduced compared to a healthy heart (bottom right corner of P-V loop). Reduced end-diastolic volume with preserved ejection fraction means that the end-systolic volume (top left corner of P-V loop) will be reduced compared to a heart with normal diastolic function.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired left ventricular contractility is consistent with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), in which case the pressure-volume loop is shifted to the right, not upwards and to the left. In HFrEF, the end-systolic volume (top left of the pressure-volume loop) is increased due to decreased contractility of the left ventricle, which results in decreased cardiac output. A compensatory increase in end-diastolic volume (bottom right) elevates preload and helps maintain stroke volume via the Frank-Starling mechanism. However, ejection fraction is still significantly reduced. The slope of the end-diastolic pressure-volume curve (the bottom line of the pressure-volume loop) is normal, as the ventricle can expand normally during diastolic filling.
Image Description:

The pressure-volume (P-V) loop in systolic dysfunction (yellow): Loss of contractility in systolic dysfunction reduces the slope of the line depicting the end-systolic P-V relationship. Therefore, the end-systolic volume (top left corner of P-V loop) appears increased compared to the normal P-V loop (green). The end-diastolic volume (bottom right corner of P-V loop) is also increased because of normal venous return to a high end-systolic volume. This higher end-diastolic volume partially increases the stroke volume via the Frank-Starling mechanism.

The P-V loop in diastolic dysfunction (blue): Increased stiffness of the ventricle in diastolic dysfunction means that the line depicting the diastolic P-V curve is shifted upwards and to the left. For any given diastolic volume, the ventricular pressure is higher in a dysfunctional heart compared to a healthy heart (green loop), and the end-diastolic volume is reduced compared to a healthy heart (bottom right corner of P-V loop). Reduced end-diastolic volume with preserved ejection fraction means that the end-systolic volume (top left corner of P-V loop) will be reduced compared to a heart with normal diastolic function.

E) INCORRECT:

The pressure-volume loop in aortic stenosis (AS) is narrower and taller than normal, not shifted upwards and to the left. In AS, the increased height of the pressure-volume loop is due to left ventricular outflow obstruction, which increases the peak left ventricular pressure during systole, and the pressure-volume loop is narrower because the increased afterload from aortic stenosis leads to decreased stroke volume.
questions.hint: This patient's pressure-volume loop shows increased left ventricular pressures for a given volume during the filling phase of diastole (i.e., a decreased ability to expand in volume in response to pressure), indicating diastolic dysfunction.

questions.text: An investigator is studying early post-mortem changes in the lung. Autopsies are performed on patients who died following recent hospital admissions. Microscopic examination of the lungs at one of the autopsies shows numerous macrophages with brown intracytoplasmic inclusions. A Prussian blue stain causes these inclusions to turn purple. These findings are most consistent with a pathological process that would manifest with which of the following symptoms?

choices.text: Dry cough that worsens early in the morning
Purulent expectoration that worsens in the lateral recumbent position
Lower extremity swelling that worsens on standing
Chest pain that improves when leaning forward
Shortness of breath that worsens when supine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diaphoresis that worsens at night is a nonspecific symptom, but it is often associated with pulmonary tuberculosis. Histopathological findings include visualization of acid-fast bacilli and caseating granulomas, and epithelioid macrophages which may coalesce to form giant cells. Hemosiderin-laden macrophages, however, would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Dry cough that worsens early in the morning is often associated with emphysematous chronic obstructive pulmonary disease caused by inflammation distal to the terminal bronchioles. Histopathologic examination would reveal alveolar wall destruction and airspace enlargement through inflammation and submucosal fibrosis. Hemosiderin-laden macrophages, however, would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Purulent expectoration that worsens in the lateral recumbent position is a sign of lower respiratory tract infection (e.g., pneumonia, lung abscess). Histological examinations would reveal alveoli filled with inflammatory cells and fluid exudate. Hemosiderin-laden macrophages, however, would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Bilateral lower extremity swelling that worsens on standing frequently occurs after right-sided heart failure. This swelling is typically a pitting edema and is caused by backup of blood in the systemic venous system. Other features of right-sided heart failure include congestive hepatomegaly, ascites, and jugular venous distension. Hemosiderin-laden macrophages are a feature of left-sided heart failure, however, not right-sided heart failure.

E) INCORRECT:

Chest pain that improves when leaning forward is associated with acute pericarditis. On autopsy, thickening of the serous and fibrous layers of the pericardium would be seen due to infiltration of fluid and immune cells. Hemosiderin-laden macrophages, however, would not be expected.

F) CORRECT:

Shortness of breath that worsens when supine and is relieved by sitting up is known as orthopnea, which is a common clinical feature of left-sided heart failure (but not right-sided heart failure). This shortness of breath is often pronounced at night, resulting in bouts of coughing (paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea). Symptoms of left heart failure result from inability of the left ventricle to maintain cardiac output, causing blood to back up in the pulmonary capillary system. Heart failure cells form as a result of alveolar macrophages phagocytosing leaked erythrocytes after pulmonary capillary rupture. Excess iron from the phagocytosed erythrocytes is broken down into hemosiderin, which can be visualized using Prussian blue staining.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Accumulations of hemosiderin-laden macrophages, known as siderophages (examples indicated by blue overlay), are visible within alveoli. Additionally, alveoli filled with erythrocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen.

Siderophages in pulmonary alveoli (heart failure cells) suggest decompensated heart failure.
questions.hint: The findings at autopsy are consistent with hemosiderin-containing macrophages.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath, dry cough, and fatigue. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, metformin, and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), heart rate is 97/min, and blood pressure is 102/61 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows an S3 gallop and coarse crackles at the lung bases. There is 1+ ankle edema bilaterally. Which of the following sets of hemodynamic changes is most likely in this patient?



Cardiac output
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
Total peripheral resistance
Mixed venous oxygen content



A
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


B
Decreased
increased
increased
decreased


C
Decreased
normal
increased
decreased


D
Decreased
decreased
increased
decreased


E
Increased
decreased
decreased
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These parameters are seen in the late stages of untreated distributive shock (e.g., due to sepsis). Inflammatory mediators lead to systemic vasodilation and decreased peripheral vascular resistance, both of which decrease the effective circulating volume. This subsequently results in low left ventricular end-diastolic volume and decreased PCWP. In the later stages of shock, the heart can no longer compensate; cardiac output and mixed venous oxygen content begin to fall, resulting in combined shock (e.g., distributive shock and cardiogenic shock). However, patients with this set of hemodynamic parameters would be critically ill and present with abnormal vital parameters such as hypotension, tachycardia or bradycardia, and fever or hypothermia, none of which is seen here.

B) CORRECT:

In left heart failure, poor contractility leads to decreased stroke volume and decreased cardiac output. Because the low cardiac output does not allow oxygen demand in peripheral tissues to be met, a higher proportion of oxygen than normal is extracted from the blood, resulting in a lower mixed venous oxygen content. With increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume and poor forward flow, left ventricular pressure increases and is transmitted to the left atrium, resulting in increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. Decreased cardiac output also results in activation of RAAS and the sympathetic nervous system, leading to increased peripheral vascular resistance and enhanced sodium and water retention. Although these changes compensate for low cardiac output initially, persistent neurohumoral activation further promotes sodium and water retention, cardiac dysfunction, and myocyte hypertrophy.

C) INCORRECT:

These parameters are consistent with obstructive shock, e.g., in a patient with massive pulmonary embolism or pericardial tamponade. In obstructive shock, venous return remains the same but cannot be transmitted through the heart chambers effectively. This results in decreased left ventricular end-diastolic volume and cardiac output. Decreased cardiac output and effective circulating volume activate the RAAS and sympathetic nervous system, resulting in increased peripheral vascular resistance. In addition, low cardiac output leads to decreased mixed venous oxygen content. Depending on the extent of obstruction, PCWP may be decreased or unchanged. Patients with obstructive shock are most often hypotensive with compensatory tachycardia, neither of which is seen this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

These parameters are consistent with hypovolemic shock (e.g., due to hemorrhage). With decreased circulating blood volume, there is reduced venous return to the heart, which results in decreased PCWP, left ventricular end-diastolic volume, and cardiac output. Decreased cardiac output and effective circulating volume activate the RAAS and sympathetic nervous system, resulting in increased peripheral vascular resistance. In addition, low cardiac output leads to decreased mixed venous oxygen content. Patients with hypovolemic shock are most often hypotensive with compensatory tachycardia, neither of which is observed in this patient. Moreover, these hemodynamic changes are unlikely to be seen in this patient, as there is no reported volume depletion.

E) INCORRECT:

These parameters are seen in the early stages of untreated septic shock. Inflammatory mediators lead to systemic vasodilation and decreased peripheral vascular resistance, both of which result in decreased effective circulating volume. This subsequently leads to low left ventricular end-diastolic volume and decreased PCWP. In the early stages of sepsis, the heart compensates with hyperdynamic function, resulting in increased cardiac output. Increased blood flow to peripheral tissues decreases the proportion of O2 that is extracted from the blood, causing an increase in mixed venous oxygen content. However, patients in the hyperdynamic phase of septic shock classically present with flushed, warm skin, fever, hypotension, and bounding pulses, none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: This patient's dyspnea, peripheral edema, signs of pulmonary edema (coarse pulmonary crackles), and S3 gallop suggest left heart failure. Given her risk factors (type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease), she most likely has underlying ischemic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath, exercise intolerance, and cough for the past 6 months. He is no longer able to climb a full flight of stairs without resting and uses 3 pillows to sleep at night. He has a history of using cocaine in his early 30s but has not used any illicit drugs for the past 20 years. His pulse is 99/min, respiratory rate is 21/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral fluffy infiltrates and thickening of the interlobar fissures, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Which of the following findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased pulmonary vascular resistance would not be expected in a patient with congestive heart failure. CHF is characterized by reduced cardiac output that results in a backup of blood in the pulmonary vasculature. The ensuing pulmonary venous congestion causes an increase in pulmonary vascular resistance.

B) CORRECT:

Poor left ventricular function impairs the forward flow of blood and subsequently results in excess blood within the pulmonary vasculature. This excess of blood leads to vascular engorgement, extravasation due to increased hydrostatic pressure, and pulmonary edema. Increased fluid within the lungs makes the lungs stiffer, reducing lung compliance.

C) INCORRECT:

Forced expiratory volume (FEV) is most commonly reduced by obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, COPD), which can present with dyspnea, exercise intolerance, cough, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette (due to right ventricular hypertrophy). However, auscultation would reveal bilateral wheezes and a chest x-ray would show features of pulmonary hyperinflation (e.g., increased radiolucency, flattening of the diaphragm). Crackles and fluffy infiltrates would not be expected. This patient's presentation is more consistent with CHF, which would not significantly affect FEV.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased carbon dioxide production is one of the causes of hypercapnia and may be due to physiologic states (e.g., exercise) or pathologic conditions (e.g., sepsis). This patient's presentation is consistent with CHF, which would be unlikely to cause an increase in carbon dioxide production.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased residual volume (RV) due to air trapping is seen in obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, COPD), which can present with dyspnea, exercise intolerance, cough, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette (due to right ventricular hypertrophy). However, auscultation would reveal bilateral wheezes and a chest x-ray would show features of pulmonary hyperinflation (e.g., increased radiolucency, flattening of the diaphragm). Crackles and fluffy infiltrates would not be expected. This patient's presentation is more consistent with CHF, which would be associated with a normal or reduced residual volume as a result of cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
questions.hint: This patient's history of reduced exercise tolerance and orthopnea, physical examination showing crackles and hypotension, and imaging showing cardiomegaly and pulmonary edema are highly suggestive of congestive heart failure (CHF) due to left ventricular dysfunction.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of severe substernal chest pain at rest. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and alcohol use disorder. He is diaphoretic and appears anxious. The lungs are clear to auscultation. An ECG shows ST-segment elevations in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6. One hour later, he develops dyspnea and a productive cough with frothy sputum. Which of the following best describes the most likely underlying pathophysiology of this patient's dyspnea?

choices.text: Transudation of plasma into the alveoli
Localized constriction of the pulmonary vasculature
Bacterial infiltration into the pulmonary parenchyma
Acute obstruction of a pulmonary artery segment
Increased permeability of pulmonary vascular endothelial cells
Elevated capacity of the pulmonary lymphatic system

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Considering this patient's recent myocardial infarction, his clinical findings of dyspnea and cough are consistent with pulmonary edema as a result of acute left heart failure. Transudation of plasma into the alveoli is the underlying pathomechanism of acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It is caused by a sudden elevation in pulmonary capillary pressure due to a decline in systolic and diastolic function, without accompanying change in the permeability of the pulmonary vascular endothelium.

B) INCORRECT:

Localized pulmonary vasoconstriction is a physiologic response mechanism (hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction) and would not explain the dyspnea and cough following this patient's myocardial infarction. Chronic hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction manifests with signs of increased pulmonary resistance, pulmonary arterial hypertension, and right-sided heart failure, which are not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial infiltration into the pulmonary parenchyma is the underlying pathomechanism of bacterial pneumonia. Although this patient's alcohol use disorder puts him at an increased risk of developing bacterial pneumonia (weakened immune system and increased chance of aspiration), his recent myocardial infarction and the frothy sputum are indicative of another underlying pathophysiology of his pulmonary symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) is caused by an acute obstruction of a pulmonary artery segment by a thrombus. PEs manifest with the acute onset of dyspnea and productive cough. However, this patient's history shows no risk factors for PE or thrombosis, and his recent myocardial infarction is not known to be a trigger event for PE.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased permeability of pulmonary vascular endothelial cells is the underlying pathomechanism of lung injury due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). While ARDS could explain this patient's shortness of breath and cough, he does not currently have any risk factors for this condition (e.g., sepsis, aspiration, trauma, pancreatitis). Moreover, his recent myocardial infarction makes a different underlying pathophysiology of his symptoms more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic heart failure develop an elevated capacity of lymphatic vessels as a response to chronically increased pulmonary transudation. This patient most likely has acute left heart failure as a result of his recent myocardial infarction. His pulmonary lymphatics cannot compensate for the acutely increased pulmonary fluid load by increasing their capacity.
questions.hint: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms (chest pain and ST-segment elevations) suggest an acute anterolateral myocardial infarction, most likely involving the left circumflex artery.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive swelling of her legs, shortness of breath on exertion, and abdominal discomfort for the past 3 months. She has also had nausea and decreased appetite, resulting in a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss. She is being treated with paclitaxel for ovarian cancer and has had 2 episodes of pulmonary embolism during the past year. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years and drinks two glasses of wine daily. She appears tired. The patient is 164 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (119 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival icterus, protuberant abdomen with a fluid wave and shifting dullness, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is visible distention of the jugular veins. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cancer is a risk factor for liver metastases, which can, in some cases, manifest with features of congestive hepatopathy (abdominal distension, ascites, jaundice) and/or peripheral edema if part of the hepatic venous system is compressed. In the majority of cases, however, liver metastases are asymptomatic. Moreover, they do not explain this patient's JVD.

B) INCORRECT:

Adverse effects of paclitaxel include hepatotoxicity, peripheral edema, and nausea. However, paclitaxel-associated hepatotoxicity is usually limited to asymptomatic elevations of serum aminotransferases; jaundice and ascites are not common. Moreover, the toxicity profile of paclitaxel does not explain this patient's JVD.

C) CORRECT:

Signs of systemic venous congestion (JVD and bilateral lower extremity edema) and reduced right heart output (dyspnea on exertion with clear lungs on auscultation) are consistent with right heart failure. This patient's right ventricular failure is likely due to recurrent malignancy-associated pulmonary embolism, which leads to an increase in pulmonary artery pressure and right ventricular afterload. Over time, this increased ventricular afterload induces right heart remodeling with consequent right ventricular dysfunction. In severe cases, patients may also develop features of hepatic congestion (e.g., abdominal distention, jaundice, and ascites) and/or gastric congestion (e.g., nausea and early satiety). Management of decompensated right heart failure includes oxygen therapy (if the patient is hypoxemic), fluid restriction, diuretic therapy, and treatment of any underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Liver cirrhosis manifests with peripheral edema, nausea, early satiety, jaundice, abdominal pain, and ascites. Cirrhosis does not, however, explain this patient's JVD. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic findings of cirrhosis (e.g., telangiectasia, caput medusae). In addition, this patient has no known risk factors for cirrhosis (e.g., history of significant alcohol use, obesity, chronic hepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Budd-Chiari syndrome manifests with features of congestive hepatopathy (abdominal distension, ascites, jaundice), and this patient's history of ovarian cancer increases the risk of developing this condition (due to cancer-associated hypercoagulability). Budd-Chiari syndrome does not, however, explain this patient's jugular distension.
Image Description:

Budd-Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow obstruction, most commonly caused by the occlusion or partial occlusion of at least two major hepatic veins (e.g., due to thrombosis).

The subsequent hepatic venous congestion leads to increased sinusoidal pressure, cellular hypoxia, and centrilobular necrosis, resulting in hepatomegaly and, eventually, a nutmeg liver.
questions.hint: If left untreated, this patient would also develop jugular venous distention (JVD) with inspiration or deep palpation of the right upper quadrant.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute-onset shortness of breath. She has a history of hypertension but no known cardiac disease.
On examination, she has a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 192/96 mm Hg. Her jugular venous pressure is elevated, but she has no murmurs. She has bibasilar crackles in her lungs. Her lower extremities show symmetrical 1+ edema. She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
A bedside echocardiogram reveals concentric left ventricular hypertrophy and hyperdynamic wall motion, with an estimated left ventricular ejection fraction of 70%. The patient has no valvular regurgitation, stenosis, or outflow-tract abnormalities.
Which one of the following cardiac conditions is most likely to be the cause of this patient’s dyspnea?

choices.text: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by an LV outflow tract murmur that increases with provocative maneuvers (i.e., Valsalva) and by echocardiographic findings of dynamic LV outflow obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is usually characterized by predominant peripheral venous congestion (right-sided heart failure) and echocardiographic evidence of infiltrative heart disease, with signs of elevated intracardiac pressures that result in dilated atria and a restrictive filling pattern.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic constrictive pericarditis is rare and has features, such as pericardial thickening and calcification, that are typically visualized during echocardiography.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is often associated with a midsystolic click and may be associated with a late systolic murmur. It is generally a benign condition unless it is complicated by mitral regurgitation.

E) CORRECT:

Acute heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is defined as clinical heart failure (edema, rales, and elevated filling pressures) in a patient with a normal left ventricular (LV) ejection fraction.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with edema, rales, elevated filling pressures, and a normal left ventricular ejection fraction is heart failure.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man with nonischemic cardiomyopathy (left ventricular ejection fraction, 25%), hypertension, type 2 diabetes, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and hypothyroidism reports mild dyspnea when he showers and an exercise tolerance of only 20 yards. He has been hospitalized three times during the past year for heart failure exacerbations.
His current medications are carvedilol 12.5 mg twice daily, sacubitril-valsartan 49/51 mg twice daily, dapagliflozin 10 mg once daily, furosemide 80 mg twice daily, metformin 500 mg twice daily, and levothyroxine 75 μg once daily.
His heart rate is 56 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 102/75 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 96% while he is breathing ambient air. His jugular venous pressure is estimated at 9 cm. His heart rhythm is regular, and he has no audible murmurs. His lungs are clear. He has 1+ lower-extremity edema and is 0.9 kg above his dry weight.
His serum creatinine concentration is 1.1 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3), and his serum potassium level is 3.8 mEq/liter (3.5–5.0). His serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in caring for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine alone does not improve outcomes in patients with heart failure. Hydralazine plus a nitrate can be considered in patients who have left ventricular systolic dysfunction and heart failure symptoms but are not able to take angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blockers. This combination can also be considered as an adjunctive therapy in patients who have persistent symptoms despite treatment with an ACE inhibitor, a beta-blocker, and a diuretic; data for this treatment regimen are stronger in Black patients.

B) INCORRECT:

When possible, the beta-blocker carvedilol should be gradually titrated to at least 25 mg twice daily in patients who have heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. However, increasing the beta-blocker dose is not indicated in this patient because he is already bradycardic and his blood pressure is already relatively low.

C) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine is used to relieve angina but has no benefit on cardiovascular outcomes in patients with heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Isosorbide mononitrate is used to relieve angina but has no benefit on cardiovascular outcomes in patients with heart failure.

E) CORRECT:

In patients with left ventricular systolic dysfunction and heart failure symptoms despite treatment with an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor, a beta-blocker, and a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor, spironolactone has been shown to reduce the risks for mortality and heart failure hospitalizations. When this drug is introduced, serum creatinine and serum potassium levels should be monitored closely.

Key learning point: A patient with New York Heart Association class III heart failure symptoms, a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%, type 2 diabetes, and a history of frequent hospitalizations should receive an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor, a beta-blocker, a diuretic, a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor, and a mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents for routine follow-up 4 days after a hospitalization for an anterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction. At discharge, an echocardiogram revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%. He was managed medically, and no intervention was performed.
His discharge medications are aspirin, clopidogrel, a beta-blocker, an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, and a statin.
When would implantation of a cardioverter-defibrillator be indicated in this patient?

choices.text: If Holter monitoring demonstrates nonsustained ventricular tachycardia
If the patient develops recurrent angina
If the patient develops intolerance to the beta-blocker
If the ejection fraction remains ≤35% at least 40 days after the myocardial infarction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonsustained ventricular tachycardia is not, in itself, an indication for ICD placement.

B) INCORRECT:

Recurrent angina is not an indication for ICD placement.

C) INCORRECT:

Approved post-MI medications (beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors) may help to improve left ventricular systolic function but do not negate the benefits of an ICD if the left ventricular ejection fraction remains ≤35%. An ICD is not indicated for medication intolerance.

D) CORRECT:

According to 2017 guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association, certain patients should have an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placed after myocardial infarction (MI) in order to prevent sudden cardiac death. This includes:

• Patients who have both a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) ≤30% and New York Heart Association (NYHA) class I symptoms at least 40 days after the MI
• Patients who have both an LVEF ≤35% and NYHA class II or III symptoms at least 40 days after MI

Of note, patients who underwent revascularization after MI should wait 90 days before placement of an ICD, as the LVEF may recover during that time with guideline-directed medical therapy.

Key learning point: After a myocardial infarction, an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is indicated if the patient has a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% or less at least 40 days after the infarction.

E) INCORRECT:

Placement of an ICD in the first 40 days after MI has no benefit and may cause harm.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman reports a one-year history of stable exertional dyspnea upon walking 2 blocks or climbing one flight of stairs. She has a history of coronary artery disease, coronary stenting, ischemic cardiomyopathy, hypertension, and tobacco use. She does not have exertional angina. Her current medications are carvedilol, lisinopril, furosemide, aspirin, and atorvastatin at maximally tolerated doses.
Her heart rate is 56 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 129/80 mm Hg, and her oxygen saturation is 97% while she is breathing ambient air. Her weight (72 kg) and BMI (26.1) have been stable for 6 months. Three months ago, an echocardiogram revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 29%.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
140
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.9
3.5–5.0


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
20
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
0.6–1.1


In addition to smoking-cessation counseling, which one of the following medication changes would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Several treatment options are available for patients who have depressed left ventricular systolic function and heart failure symptoms despite treatment with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor (or a similar agent such as an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor [ARNI] or an angiotensin-receptor blocker [ARB]) in combination with a beta-blocker. These options can be combined as necessary and include:

• Adding a mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist, such as eplerenone. Mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonists have been shown to improve survival in this setting. Patients with a depressed ejection fraction and heart failure symptoms may be considered for a mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist if the serum potassium level is <5.0 mEq/liter and the serum creatinine concentration is ≤2.5 mg/dL for men or ≤2.0 mg/dL for women.
• Switching the patient’s ACE inhibitor or ARB to an ARNI. Current guidelines give this strategy a class Ib recommendation for improving morbidity and mortality.
• Adding a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor, such as dapagliflozin or empagliflozin. Two recent clinical trials showed that these agents reduce heart failure hospitalization and cardiovascular mortality irrespective of diabetes status.

Key learning point: Patients with heart failure and a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction should be treated with a beta-blocker and either an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, or an angiotensin-receptor blocker. If symptoms persist, then the clinician can add a mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist, a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor, or both

B) INCORRECT:

Digoxin can reduce hospitalizations in patients with heart failure but does not improve survival, so it is not the first treatment choice.

C) INCORRECT:

In a patient with chronic cardiomyopathy and well-controlled blood pressure who is receiving a beta-blocker and an ACE inhibitor, adding an ARB (e.g., losartan) would not improve survival and may cause harm (hypotension, hyperkalemia, kidney failure).

D) INCORRECT:

Replacing carvedilol with metoprolol would not be expected to improve symptoms or survival.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with well-controlled blood pressure, adding amlodipine to an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker has not been shown to improve outcomes.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old woman who, 3 days ago, underwent primary percutaneous coronary intervention for an anterior myocardial infarction is found to have a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%. She has had no arrhythmias during her hospitalization. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
Her husband has an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), and she asks whether she should have one placed.
Which one of the following recommendations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend that an ICD be placed before hospital discharge
Reassure her that she is unlikely to benefit from an ICD
Defer consideration of an ICD until an echocardiogram has been obtained in 3 months
Defer consideration of an ICD until a postdischarge ambulatory Holter evaluation has been completed
Recommend that an ICD be placed 6 weeks after the date of infarction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ICD placement is appropriate before discharge in a patient who has ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation more than 24 hours after the MI.

B) INCORRECT:

An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) should be considered if the patient meets one of these two criteria:

• Persistent LV dysfunction (LV ejection fraction <35%) despite optimal medical therapy (a beta-blocker, an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, and a statin, with or without spironolactone)
• A malignant ventricular arrhythmia (ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation) more than 24 hours after the MI

C) CORRECT:

Left ventricular (LV) dysfunction after a myocardial infarction (MI) predisposes the patient to ventricular arrhythmias and increased risk for sudden cardiac death.

Current guidelines recommend echocardiographic evaluation of LV systolic function for an ICD a minimum of 40 days (about 6 weeks) after an MI or 3 months after primary percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass surgery. By then, stunned myocardium may have recovered its function and/or ventricular remodeling may have occurred, resulting in an improvement in LV function and obviating the need for an ICD.

Key learning point: Patients who have undergone primary percutaneous intervention (PCI) for myocardial infarction should undergo an assessment of left ventricular dysfunction to determine eligibility for an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator no earlier than 3 months after the PCI.

D) INCORRECT:

An ambulatory Holter evaluation is not necessary to determine suitability for an ICD.

E) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines recommend echocardiographic evaluation of LV systolic function for an ICD a minimum of 40 days (about 6 weeks) after an MI or 3 months after primary percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass surgery. By then, stunned myocardium may have recovered its function and/or ventricular remodeling may have occurred, resulting in an improvement in LV function and obviating the need for an ICD.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man’s blood pressure readings have ranged from 148 to 155 mm Hg systolic and from 93 to 97 mm Hg diastolic at his past two clinic visits. He currently takes a maximal dose of carvedilol as well as amlodipine 5 mg daily and reports leg edema when he uses higher doses.
He has a history of mildly symptomatic benign prostatic hyperplasia and had angina 4 years ago, for which two drug-eluting stents were placed in his left circumflex artery. He is physically active and has experienced no anginal symptoms since his stents were placed. He has mild orthopnea and sleeps on two pillows each night. He has mild dyspnea on exertion but no dyspnea at rest.
His current medications are aspirin, carvedilol, furosemide, amlodipine, tamsulosin, finasteride, simvastatin, and sildenafil as needed for erectile dysfunction.
His weight is 82 kg, his BMI is 27.5, his blood pressure is 154/96 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 68 beats per minute. There is a soft third heart sound. He has a mild elevation in his jugular venous pulse. There is trace lower-extremity edema. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory testing reveals normal sodium, potassium, and creatinine concentrations. An echocardiogram performed 12 months ago showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 39%.
Which one of the following medications should be added to this patient’s regimen?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients who have heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF; ejection fraction ≤40%) should be treated with medications that have been shown to provide clinical benefit in reducing symptoms, hospital admissions for heart failure, and/or mortality. All patients should be treated with a beta-blocker and one of the following: an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, an angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB), or a combination of an ARB and a neprilysin inhibitor (known together as an ARNI).

Of the options provided for this particular patient, adding the ARNI sacubitril-valsartan would be the preferred approach. Sacubitril-valsartan is the only currently available ARNI and has been shown to reverse cardiac remodeling seen in heart failure, to rapidly improve patient-reported outcomes, to reduce hospitalizations for heart failure, and to reduce mortality. Given these benefits, ARNIs are preferred over ACE inhibitors or ARBs, although the latter two classes are still acceptable options when ARNI use is not feasible (usually due to cost).

Key learning point: Initial therapy for all patients who have heart failure with reduced ejection fraction should include a beta-blocker and one of the following: an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor, an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, or an angiotensin-receptor blocker.

B) INCORRECT:

Treatment with an alpha-blocker such as doxazosin would lower blood pressure but has not been found to have any other benefits in heart failure management. Doxazosin was, in fact, found to increase the risk of heart failure in the ALLHAT trial. The current primary role for these medications is in managing symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), but this patient’s BPH symptoms are mild and do not warrant treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Isosorbide mononitrate is a long-acting nitrate used for symptomatic chest pain. It is not used alone in heart failure. The combination of isosorbide mononitrate and hydralazine was shown in the A-HeFT trial to have a survival benefit as unloading therapy in heart failure, but it is considered second-line therapy in this setting, to be used only if a patient cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors, ARBs, or ARNIs. These agents all have a greater level of evidence of benefit in this setting than isosorbide mononitrate-hydralazine.

D) INCORRECT:

Treatment with an alpha-blocker such as terazosin would lower blood pressure but has not been found to have any other benefits in heart failure management. The current primary role for these medications is in managing symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), but this patient’s BPH symptoms are mild and do not warrant treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Thiazides such as hydrochlorothiazide would lower blood pressure but do not reverse cardiac remodeling seen in heart failure. A different drug is more likely to reduce mortality and improve prognosis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man with no significant medical history is hospitalized with new-onset shortness of breath, orthopnea, bilateral leg swelling, and subjective chills, all of which developed during the past 2 weeks.
At presentation, laboratory evaluation revealed elevated cardiac biomarkers, a normal chemistry panel, and a normal complete blood count; initial blood cultures were negative. A chest radiograph revealed features of pulmonary edema, and a subsequent transthoracic echocardiogram revealed left ventricular global hypokinesis, a left ventricular ejection fraction of 34%, and normal valvular function. Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography showed normal coronary arteries, and cardiac MRI findings were consistent with a suspected diagnosis of viral myocarditis.
The patient is currently afebrile. He has a blood pressure of 135/78 mm Hg, a heart rate of 83 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 96% while breathing 2 liters of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. He has bibasilar crackles, trace lower-extremity edema, and a jugular venous pressure of 9 cm.
In addition to diuresis, which one of the following approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain acute and convalescent viral titers

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myocarditis can be caused by a variety of infectious and noninfectious sources. In some cases, a specific underlying cause may never be identified. Regardless of etiology, the treatment for myocarditis causing a reduced ejection fraction relies on the same agents that are used to treat heart failure with reduced ejection fraction from other etiologies:

• All patients should receive agents shown to prevent progressive remodeling, which are a beta-blocker and an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) or, if an ARNI is not available, an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor or angiotensin-receptor blocker.
• In patients who currently have or previously had signs and symptoms of heart failure, a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor and/or a mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist should be added.

Diuretic therapy can be used to manage persistent volume overload despite optimized medical therapy with the other agents listed above.

Routine endomyocardial biopsy is not necessary for this patient. It is usually reserved for patients who worsen or do not improve with standard therapy or for suspected specific causes of myocarditis (e.g., giant-cell, sarcoid, or eosinophilic).

Key learning point: Patients who have viral myocarditis and clinically stable heart failure with reduced ejection fraction should be managed with diuretic therapy and an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor.

B) INCORRECT:

Routine immunosuppressive therapy (with medications such as prednisone) is not recommended in this setting. It is generally reserved for rapidly progressive heart failure from causes such as giant-cell, sarcoid, or eosinophilic myocarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, such as indomethacin, have been shown to worsen outcomes in murine models of myocarditis; their use should be avoided in patients with viral myocarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is indicated for acute pericarditis, not myocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Testing peripheral blood for viral serologies has a low yield and does not correlate well with biopsy results in patients with viral myocarditis.

questions.text:
An 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and heart failure with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction presents for outpatient follow-up. For the past month, she has experienced worsening dyspnea on exertion that is now apparent when she walks up one flight of stairs (a task she previously tolerated). She also reports orthopnea (although this has improved since she added a second pillow at night), nausea, and poor appetite. In addition, her chronic leg edema has progressed from including only her ankles to now reaching her knees. During the past week, she increased her diuretic dosing from furosemide 40 mg each morning to twice daily (as previously directed in the event of worsening edema), but she has not noticed any change in her symptoms. She follows a sodium-restricted diet.
Physical examination reveals a body weight of 73.5 kg (up from 70 kg at her last visit 4 months ago), a blood pressure of 124/81 mm Hg, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, an oxygen saturation of 92% while she breathes ambient air, and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Jugular venous pressure is estimated at 14 cm of water, increases to 18 cm when abdominal pressure is applied, and remains elevated for 30 seconds after abdominal pressure is released.
Cardiac examination reveals normal first and second heart sounds, no S3 or S4, and a 2/6 holosystolic murmur that radiates to the left axilla. There are bibasilar crackles to the mid-lung fields bilaterally. The abdomen is protuberant without fluid wave, and bowel sounds are diminished. The lower extremities have 2+ pitting edema to the knees bilaterally. The extremities are warm with normal distal pulses. Capillary refill occurs in <2 seconds.
Laboratory testing reveals no significant changes since the patient’s last visit, except for her serum creatinine level, which has increased from 0.9 mg/dL to 1.2 mg/dL (baseline, 0.9; reference range, 0.6–1.1).
What is the most appropriate next step in addressing this patient’s heart failure?

choices.text: Change furosemide to bumetanide 1 mg by mouth twice daily, and follow up in one week
Admit the patient to the hospital for intravenous diuresis
Admit the patient to the intensive care unit for inotropic-assisted diuresis
Increase furosemide to 80 mg twice daily, and follow up in one week
Make no changes, check the brain natriuretic peptide level, and follow up in one week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Switching this patient’s oral diuretic from furosemide to bumetanide could be helpful given the greater oral bioavailability of bumetanide. However, this patient has had a large weight gain and is showing signs of more severe volume overload that would benefit from close observation.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has signs of worsening volume overload and is not responding to an increased frequency of her oral diuretic dose. Loop diuretics are often described as “threshold drugs” because the concentration of the drug in the bloodstream must reach a therapeutic threshold in order to have an effect. In the setting of heart failure and/or reduced renal function, there may be an increase in sodium retention, and a higher drug concentration of loop diuretics may be required to achieve a net diuresis. Furosemide has the widest range of bioavailability of any oral loop diuretic (10%–100%, compared with 80%–100% for bumetanide and torsemide), and bowel edema in the setting of diffuse volume overload can limit bioavailability even further. Therefore, patients with decompensated heart failure should be treated with intravenous diuresis.

Key learning point: The next step in management for a patient who is not responsive to escalating doses of oral diuretics is to administer intravenous diuretics.

C) INCORRECT:

Given that the patient is not in severe distress and exhibits signs of normal perfusion, inotropic support is not warranted.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing the furosemide dose could help, but this patient has had a large weight gain and is showing signs of more severe volume overload that would benefit from close observation rather than outpatient treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Checking a brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level can have clinical value in diagnosing acute heart failure, particularly in patients whose symptoms have multiple possible etiologies. This patient’s BNP level is likely to be elevated, given her heart failure and worsening renal function, but this would not change her management.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidemia presents with progressive bilateral edema that he first noticed 6 weeks ago. Initially, the edema would improve in the mornings, but now it persists throughout the day. The patient reports that he was previously able to walk a mile without stopping but can now walk only one block because of shortness of breath, which subsides with rest. He also describes shortness of breath at night, which improves when he sits up. He is a current smoker with a 25-pack-year history who binge drinks on the weekends. He currently takes simvastatin 20 mg daily.
On physical examination, he is afebrile and has a blood pressure of 138/73 mm Hg, a heart rate of 73 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while he breathes ambient air. His BMI is 31.
Cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm without rub or gallop. The point of maximal impulse is laterally displaced. Jugular venous pressure is mildly elevated. Breath sounds are diminished with bibasilar crackles and an occasional expiratory wheeze. The abdomen is soft but mildly distended. There is no hepatosplenomegaly and no fluid wave. There is 2+ peripheral pitting edema to both calves.
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus rhythm with nonspecific ST/T-wave changes.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ultrasound of the right upper quadrant would be appropriate if cirrhosis were the most likely diagnosis. This patient has a history of binge drinking, but no significant ascites or stigmata of liver disease were noted during his physical examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the patient's occasional expiratory wheeze and history of tobacco use raise concern for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, this diagnosis would not explain the patient's lower-extremity edema, bibasilar crackles, or elevated jugular venous pressure. Pulmonary function tests may be appropriate eventually but are not the best next step at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation is less consistent with deep-vein thrombosis (DVT) than heart failure, because the edema is symmetric and there are no clear risk factors for DVT. Thus, a lower-extremity venous duplex ultrasound is not an appropriate next step.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with new-onset heart failure; several of his physical examination findings (bibasilar crackles, elevated jugular venous pressure, bilateral edema) are consistent with volume overload. Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the underlying cause of heart failure in roughly two-thirds of patients with reduced systolic function; this patient’s alcohol consumption also places him at increased risk for alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy. The 2022 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guidelines for the management of heart failure include a class I recommendation for echocardiography in patients suspected of having heart failure.

Key learning point: In a patient with progressive shortness of breath and volume overload, the most appropriate diagnostic study to perform is echocardiography.

E) INCORRECT:

An exercise tolerance test is the most appropriate study in patients who have an intermediate pretest probability for CAD. In patients with new-onset heart failure, the probability of CAD is high; assessment of cardiac function by echocardiography is a more appropriate initial test, because it will provide important hemodynamic data and help identify a potential underlying cause of the heart failure. Depending on the echocardiogram findings, further evaluation for CAD might be appropriate.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up after a recent hospitalization for volume overload and dyspnea. She has felt much better since discharge, without any residual exercise intolerance. Her medication regimen includes metformin 1000 mg twice daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, and furosemide 20 mg daily.
She has a temperature of 37.2°C, a blood pressure of 115/70 mm Hg, a heart rate of 70 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals a laterally displaced point of maximal impulse with a 2/6 holosystolic murmur heard at the cardiac apex. Jugular venous pressure is visualized at 6 cm of water while the patient lies at a 45° angle. Hepatojugular reflux is not present. Trace bilateral pitting edema is noted.
An echocardiogram obtained during the patient’s hospitalization reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction of 34%, with global hypokinesis and mild-to-moderate central mitral regurgitation.
Which one of the following changes in pharmacologic management, if any, is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Leave the current regimen as is

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

When a patient who has heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is stable and is already taking an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, the most appropriate pharmacologic addition is a beta-blocker. Three beta-blockers have been shown to reduce long-term mortality in patients with HFrEF: bisoprolol, carvedilol, and long-acting metoprolol.

Key learning point: For a patient with a recent diagnosis of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction who is currently asymptomatic, has no signs of volume overload, and is already taking an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, the most appropriate next step in pharmacologic management is to add one of the following beta-blockers: bisoprolol, carvedilol, or long-acting metoprolol.

B) INCORRECT:

Both spironolactone and the combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate have been shown to reduce mortality in specific populations with HFrEF. However, beta-blockers have a stronger evidence base to support their use as first-line therapy in patients with HFrEF, with benefits including a reduction in mortality and not just symptomatic improvement. A beta-blocker should therefore be initiated in this patient first; other agents may be considered at a later time if symptoms persist.

C) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient is currently asymptomatic and her physical examination suggests euvolemia, there is no need for additional diuresis with an increased dose of furosemide.

D) INCORRECT:

Making no changes to this patient’s regimen would be inappropriate if she can tolerate beta-blockers, given their established survival benefit in this clinical scenario.

E) INCORRECT:

Both spironolactone and the combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate have been shown to reduce mortality in specific populations with HFrEF. However, beta-blockers have a stronger evidence base to support their use as first-line therapy in patients with HFrEF, with benefits including a reduction in mortality and not just symptomatic improvement. A beta-blocker should therefore be initiated in this patient first; other agents may be considered at a later time if symptoms persist.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes reports having shortness of breath for the past 2 weeks that worsens with exertion. She also reports a three-pillow orthopnea and mild ankle swelling. She reports no fevers, chills, cough, palpitations, or chest pain.
On physical examination, she has a temperature of 37.2°C, a blood pressure of 105/62 mm Hg, a heart rate of 105 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute. On lung examination, she has bibasilar crackles while sitting upright. Cardiac examination reveals a regular heart rhythm and a grade 2/6 systolic murmur that is heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla. Jugular venous pressure is visualized at 10 cm of water while the patient lies at a 45-degree angle. She has 1+ bilateral pitting edema at the ankles.
An electrocardiogram reveals normal sinus rhythm with left axis deviation and a left bundle-branch block. A newly obtained transthoracic echocardiogram shows mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, anterior-wall akinesis, lateral-wall hypokinesis, mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation, and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 32% with preserved right ventricular systolic function.
Which one of the following diagnostic evaluations is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s heart failure?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with classic signs and symptoms of volume overload, secondary to left-sided heart failure. Left ventricular (LV) wall-motion abnormalities and systolic dysfunction are evident on echocardiography. Although LV dysfunction and heart failure have many potential causes, this patient's echocardiographic findings suggest an underlying ischemic cardiomyopathy related to undiagnosed coronary artery disease (CAD), especially in the setting of diabetes.

In many situations, evaluation for underlying CAD could reasonably be pursued noninvasively, with stress testing. However, exercise tolerance testing cannot be interpreted accurately in a patient who has a baseline left bundle-branch block (as in this case). In addition, this patient has significant CAD risk factors and echocardiographic features that are highly suggestive of an ischemic cardiomyopathy; therefore, she has a very high pretest probability of CAD. Coronary angiography also provides useful anatomic information for patients who are candidates for revascularization. Given all of these factors, cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography, although invasive, would be diagnostically superior to exercise tolerance testing. If avoiding an invasive test is important, then CT coronary angiography is an option, with cardiac catheterization reserved for those patients identified as having CAD that warrants intervention. If underlying CAD is excluded, other causes of heart failure should be considered.

Key learning point: Patients with new-onset heart failure and a high likelihood of coronary artery disease (CAD) who are candidates for coronary revascularization should undergo an evaluation for CAD using either cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography or CT coronary angiography.

B) INCORRECT:

An abnormal plasma level of angiotensin-converting enzyme may suggest underlying sarcoidosis, but this test has limited sensitivity and specificity. Furthermore, no granulomas are described in this case, making this type of testing inappropriate for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemochromatosis is unlikely in this patient, making ferritin testing inappropriate. Patients whose cardiomyopathy is secondary to hemochromatosis usually present between the ages of 30 to 50. Echocardiographic findings in this condition are consistent with dilated ventricles and a global hypokinesis; regional wall-motion abnormalities are not present.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient’s echocardiographic findings are not typical for amyloidosis. In those cases, the myocardium is thickened but has a distinct hyperenhancement and a global hypokinesis, not regional wall-motion abnormalities. Serum protein electrophoresis is therefore not appropriate for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

In many situations, evaluation for underlying CAD could reasonably be pursued noninvasively, with stress testing. However, exercise tolerance testing cannot be interpreted accurately in a patient who has a baseline left bundle-branch block (as in this case). In addition, this patient has significant CAD risk factors and echocardiographic features that are highly suggestive of an ischemic cardiomyopathy; therefore, she has a very high pretest probability of CAD. Given all of these factors, cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography, although invasive, would be diagnostically superior to exercise tolerance testing.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man who is an active heavy smoker and has not adhered to his prescribed treatments for long-standing hypertension presents for evaluation of a 3-month history of dyspnea on exertion. He has a BMI of 32 and is usually sedentary. He notes that lately he becomes dyspneic after walking about half a block and that the symptoms improve with rest. He also notes that his symptoms have worsened during the past 2 weeks and that he now experiences dyspnea at night. He reports no chest pain, other angina equivalents, or palpitations.
On examination, he has a blood pressure of 160/90 mm Hg, a heart rate of 78 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. He appears comfortable at rest. Lung examination reveals mild wheezing. Heart auscultation reveals a regular rate and rhythm with a fourth heart sound and no murmur; point of maximal impulse is shifted slightly toward the midaxillary line. The patient’s abdomen is obese without organomegaly, and he has 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities up to the knee.
Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin level of 15 mg/dL (reference range, 13.5–17.5) and a serum creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL (0.8–1.3). The N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide level is 560 pg/dL (≥900 is associated with a high probability of heart failure in patients aged 50 to 75).
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus rhythm with voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy and left atrial enlargement. A chest radiograph demonstrates mild cardiomegaly and cephalization of pulmonary vessels without pulmonary opacities. Spirometry is pending.
What is the most appropriate next test to evaluate the cause of this patient’s dyspnea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Right heart catheterization is not needed to diagnose HFpEF; however, it may be useful in excluding other causes of dyspnea such as pulmonary hypertension. In cases where the pretest probability for HFpEF remains high despite noninvasive treatment, assessment of cardiac filling pressure, especially with exercise, may be needed to make the diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis in the evaluation of chronic dyspnea can be broad and at times challenging, especially in the setting of coexisting conditions. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is certainly a concern in this patient, given his history of cigarette smoking and the wheezing present on lung examination. Spirometry should be obtained to assess for COPD in this case, but the patient’s presentation also features signs and symptoms (lower-extremity edema and cephalization of pulmonary vessels on chest radiograph) that warrant further evaluation for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).

The clinical symptoms of HFpEF are the same as those of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction — dyspnea on exertion and at rest (orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea), crackles, elevated jugular venous pressure, and lower-extremity edema — but HFpEF is classically associated with one or more of the following: hypertension (with or without left ventricular hypertrophy), older age, coronary artery disease, obstructive sleep apnea, obesity, and kidney disease. Notably, although wheezing is more common with obstructive lung disease, it also occurs in airway edema associated with heart failure.

Diagnosis of HFpEF requires signs and symptoms of heart failure and evidence of preserved left ventricular function on echocardiography; other supporting features may include diastolic dysfunction, left atrial enlargement, and elevated pulmonary artery pressures. N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide testing can be helpful but may show normal results despite heart failure, especially in patients with obesity and in those with only exertional dyspnea.

Key learning point: The best test to diagnose suspected heart failure with preserved ejection fraction is echocardiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has risk factors for thromboembolic disease including obesity and smoking, the chronicity of symptoms, as well as the lack of tachypnea and tachycardia, make acute pulmonary embolism much less likely. For this reason, CT pulmonary angiography is not the most appropriate next step in evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery disease is common in patients with HFpEF, and sometimes angina symptoms may occur secondary to high filling pressures rather than epicardial coronary disease. However, this patient has no symptoms suggestive of ischemia; hence, noninvasive testing should be performed before cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography to assess whether underlying ischemia is contributing to his symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

High-resolution chest CT is important in the evaluation of chronic dyspnea; however, it would not be a first-line test in a patient whose chest radiograph shows no pulmonary opacities. If spirometry suggests restriction, full pulmonary function testing and a CT scan of the chest would be reasonable to evaluate for the presence of interstitial lung disease.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man with a history of obesity and type 2 diabetes presents for his annual physical examination.
During the past several years, his ability to exercise has been steadily declining because of knee pain. He used to be able to walk for several miles without any symptoms, but now, he can walk for only a few minutes before the pain in his knees forces him to stop. He reports mild exertional dyspnea, which he believes is related to deconditioning. He reports no chest pain, palpitations, or other cardiac symptoms. His current medications are acetaminophen and ibuprofen (as needed for knee pain), lisinopril, atorvastatin, metformin, and semaglutide.
On physical examination, his heart rate is 68 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 148/91 mm Hg, and his BMI is 34. Cardiac auscultation identifies an S4 gallop but is otherwise normal. Jugular venous pressure is 10 cm of water at 45 degrees, and trace lower-extremity edema is evident. The rest of the physical examination is normal.
Routine laboratory evaluation reveals a normal complete blood count, normal renal function, and normal coagulation parameters. The patient’s glycated hemoglobin concentration is 6.3% (reference range, 4.3–5.6), and his LDL-cholesterol level is 88 mg/dL (<130). An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate next test for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s findings on electrocardiogram (ECG) are consistent with left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH), likely related to chronic uncontrolled hypertension. Several methods can help to identify LVH on a patient’s ECG:

Sokolow-Lyon criteria

LVH is suspected if either of the following criteria are met:
• The sum of the S wave in lead V1 and the R wave in either lead V5 or lead V6 is ≥3.5 mV (35 mm)
• The R wave in lead aVL is ≥1.1 mV (11 mm)

Cornell criteria

LVH is suspected if the sum of the S wave in lead V3 and the R wave in lead aVL is >2.8 mV (28 mm) in men or >2.0 mV (20 mm) in women.

Romhilt-Estes point system

In this scoring system, 1 to 3 points are assigned for each of six ECG features. LVH is considered definite if a patient has a total score ≥5 points — and probable if the total score is 4 points.
• 3 points: In any limb lead, the R wave or S wave is ≥2.0 mV (20 mm), or the S wave in lead V1 or V2 is ≥3.0 mV (30 mm), or the R wave in lead V5 or V6 is ≥3.0 mV (30 mm)
• 3 points: ST/T-wave changes typical of LVH (“left ventricular strain” - ST-segment depression bowed upward and T-wave inversion; assign only 1 point if the patient is taking a digitalis compound)
• 3 points: Left atrial abnormality, as evident from P-terminal force (in lead V1) of ≥1 mm in depth and ≥40 msec (0.04 sec) in duration
• 2 points: Left-axis deviation –30° or more
• 1 point: QRS duration ≥90 msec (0.09 sec)
• 1 point: Intrinsicoid deflection (interval between the beginning of the QRS complex and the peak of the R wave) in lead V5 or V6 is ≥50 msec (0.05 sec)

This patient’s ECG meets precordial lead criteria for LVH according to Sokolow-Lyon criteria, as the approximate sum of the S wave in lead V1 (27 mm) and the R wave in lead V6 (32 mm) is 59 mm, which is above the 35-mm cutoff. In addition, the R wave in lead aVL is about 15 mm; thus, the second Sokolow-Lyon criterion is also fulfilled. The ECG also meets the Cornell criteria for LVH, as the approximate sum of the S wave in lead V3 (28 mm) plus the R wave in lead aVL (15 mm) is 43 mm, which is above the 28-mm cutoff for men. Finally, this ECG meets many of the criteria for LVH in the Romhilt-Estes point system, including the voltage criterion, the presence of ST/T-wave abnormalities, and ECG evidence of left atrial enlargement — for a score of at least 9, which indicates definite LVH. The clinical finding of S4 gallop is also consistent with LVH.

Imaging for LVH is not universally recommended during evaluation and management of hypertension in adults but should be considered in hypertensive patients who are young (<18 years), who have uncontrolled hypertension, who have secondary hypertension, whose blood pressure has been chronically uncontrolled, who have symptoms of heart failure, or who have ECG evidence of LVH. This patient should be further evaluated for LVH with imaging, both because of the ECG findings and because he has symptoms and signs that suggest heart failure (dyspnea on exertion, slightly elevated jugular venous pressure, and trace pedal edema). The imaging modality of choice is a complete transthoracic echocardiogram to evaluate for end-organ damage related to hypertension (not just for LVH but also for left atrial enlargement, diastolic dysfunction, systolic dysfunction, and other complications.).

Key learning point: The most appropriate next test to assess a patient who has suspected left ventricular hypertrophy, according to electrocardiographic criteria, is transthoracic echocardiography.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI would provide information about the degree and functional consequence of left ventricular hypertrophy, but a different imaging modality is typically the first-line test, given considerations of cost, accessibility, and institutional expertise in interpretation.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is not appropriate as a first-line test in an intermediate-risk patient with possible ischemic heart disease.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has symptoms that could be attributable to angina, and further evaluation for coronary ischemia may be reasonable. However, the presence of left ventricular hypertrophy on the ECG reduces the accuracy of treadmill ECG testing. A stress test that encompasses an imaging modality (either stress echocardiography or myocardial perfusion imaging) would be a better option.

E) INCORRECT:

Holter monitoring is typically indicated to detect arrhythmias, especially if there are symptoms such as unexplained palpitations or syncope, which are not present in this case. In the context of left ventricular hypertrophy, Holter monitoring is not warranted unless there is a specific indication (e.g., identifying patients with confirmed hypertrophic cardiomyopathy who qualify for an implantable cardioverter defibrillator).

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to establish care. He has a history of type 2 diabetes, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, placement of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator, stable coronary artery disease with a stent placed 3 years ago, hypertension, and pancreatitis. His medications include carvedilol 25 mg twice daily, sacubitril-valsartan 97 mg/103 mg twice daily, spironolactone 50 mg daily, torsemide 10 mg daily, and metformin 1000 mg twice daily. He reports that he is feeling well without any cardiac symptoms.
On physical examination, he has a heart rate of 62 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 136/76 mm Hg, an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air, and a weight of 70 kg. There is no jugular venous distention. The lungs are clear, and heart sounds are regular without murmurs. There is pedal edema.
Relevant laboratory results include an LDL-cholesterol level of 65 mg/dL (reference range, <130), a potassium level of 4.1 mEq/liter (3.5–5.0), and a serum creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL (0.8–1.3).
A recent echocardiogram revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%.
Which one of the following medication changes is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine-isosorbide dinitrate can be used as an alternative to renin-angiotensin inhibitors if these medications are contraindicated or not tolerated — or as an addition to these medications if a patient has persistent symptoms despite full guideline-directed medical therapy. Neither of these circumstances apply in this case.

B) CORRECT:

Patients who have heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) should receive maximal guideline-directed medical therapy to reduce the likelihood of morbidity and premature death.
